    Collection of Medical Works from Antiquity to Present, Volume 411

    Diseases of Children's Heads, Faces, Ears, Eyes, and Noses

    From "Thousand Gold Prescriptions" by Sun Simiao (Tang Dynasty)

    Head Sores

    It is said: For children with small sores on their heads, which are itchy and oozing yellow pus, and do not scab over, persisting for years without healing, are called "jealous head sores." These should be washed with Red Dragon Skin Decoction and Tianma Decoction, taken internally with Liu Lu Decoction, and externally treated with Fei Wu Gao San and Huanglian Hu Fen Mercury Gao San.

    Children's Direct Prescriptions by Qian Yi (Song Dynasty)

    Unhealed Fontanelle

    Unhealed fontanelle refers to the incomplete closure of the fontanelle at birth. Such children generally tend to be more sorrowful than joyful; their sclerae are often too prominent, their faces pale and washed out, and their bodies lean, all indicative of kidney deficiency.

    (Note: The kidneys govern marrow, and the brain is considered the sea of marrow. The aforementioned condition arises when the parents' essence and blood are insufficient to nourish the child, and it is advisable to use Di Huang Wan to replenish them. If the child reaches seven or eight years old, or fourteen or fifteen years old, when Qi and blood are strong and the fontanelle naturally closes, they may be fine. However, if indulging in food and desires depletes true Yin, their lifespan cannot be fully realized. If this condition presents in infants, the mother should also be nourished, and the child's head should be tightly wrapped in soft cloth to facilitate closure. There may also be cases of recessed or filled fontanelles, both falling under insufficient constitution. Additionally, those suffering from lingering Five Taxations with depleted vital energy should also be monitored along with similar symptoms of urinary difficulty.)[1p]

    Late Hair Growth

    If hair takes a long time to grow, and when it does, it is not black, it indicates weakness of the fetus.
    Note: This is one of the five signs of late development. Hair is a manifestation of kidney vitality. This is mainly due to insufficient essence and blood from the parents, leading to weak kidney energy that cannot nourish the hair.

    Sweet Sores

    In children, if sweet sores do not heal for a long time, they are commonly called “fragrant sores,” mainly appearing on the face and in front of the ears. One method is to have the mother chew white rice into a paste and apply it before sleeping; it should heal in three to five applications. Both the child and mother should avoid chicken, pork, fish, rabbit, wine, vinegar, and anything that induces heat and wind. The treatment for sweet fingers follows the same method.

    Facial Sores

    Facial sores in children are referred to as eyebrow sores; ear sores are called ear sores; and foot sores are known as shoe fungi. These three terms, when examined, are all misnomers. The classics say: all painful sores are related to heart heat, resulting from severe blood heat. Some say: The “Internal Classic” states that generally, heat should not be assumed to apply to all cases. This is a misunderstanding of the way of nature; care should be taken not to be misled. A gold needle may be used to prick for blood; if it does not heal after one attempt, it should be pricked again. If it still does not heal after the second attempt, it will surely heal after the third attempt. The “Internal Classic” states: Blood that is abundant should be pricked. Eyebrow sores should not be treated with medicine, as they are often itchy; scratching may occur, and if the medicine gets into the eyes, it will cause damage.[2p]
    White Scalp

    The condition known as white scalp in children is commonly referred to as chicken dung baldness. One can use sweet melon vines and dragon head; there is no specific quantity required. Soak them in river water overnight, then boil in a clay pot to extract the extremely bitter juice. After filtering out the melon vines, use low heat to reduce it to a syrupy consistency and store it in ceramic containers. Before application, shave the head to remove all scabs and dead blood, then cleanse with river water. Afterward, take a small cup of the prepared melon vine extract, add two qian of fresh pinellia powder, one tablespoon of natural ginger juice, and one piece of dog bile together to mix. A dosage of just three qian is sufficient. It is crucial to avoid chicken, pork, fish, rabbit, and any foods that induce heat or wind.

    Eye Disorders

    The "Inner Canon" states: "When heat prevails, there is swelling." To treat fire, the method involves using salty and cool medicines; emesis and purging are also effective. For acupuncture, target Shen Ting, Shang Xing, Yin Hui, Qian Ding, and Bai Hui points. Conditions like blood cloudiness can be quickly alleviated; pain can be promptly relieved; obscured vision can be restored; and swelling can be diminished. However, acupuncture should not be performed on the Yin Hui point in children, as the flesh is too thin and may damage the bones. Children’s conditions are governed by the water above and fire below, hence clear vision.

    Scabs in the Eye

    If a child's scabs enter the eye, it is due to residual heat not dissipating. The appropriate course of action is to reduce heart fire, drain liver wind, and nourish kidney water, leading to recovery.

    Malnutrition Eye

    If a child's malnutrition-related eye condition does not improve for several days, it is caused by wind-heat from the liver. Administering Liang Ge San in several doses will aid in opening the eyes and promote healing.[3p]

    Resolving Skull Issues

    Resolving skull issues occurs when the mother's energy is weak and there is an excess of heat. According to Dai Yun, for newborns whose skull bones have not yet fused and are open, it is advisable to use the Four Gentlemen Decoction and Four Substances Decoction, adding alcohol for heat, along with prepared cooked rhubarb, Scutellaria, roasted Coptis, and raw licorice, to be taken as a decoction. Externally, tie a silk cloth securely and apply a powder of white lanceolate.

    Head Sores

    For a child's head sores, use red charcoal to wash with flowing water, allowing the heat to cleanse it. Additionally, take a concoction of wine with Tong Sheng San (a traditional formula) while excluding the rhubarb prepared in wine, using ground coriander seeds, dragon’s liver, dragon's tail, Coptis, and white alum to mix into a paste for application.

    Excellent and Effective Methods

    Resolving skull issues relates to the fullness of maternal energy and blood, resulting in a firm and nurturing fontanelle in the child; if the mother is ill and her energy and blood are weak, the child's fontanelle will be soft and less substantial. The posterior fontanelle relates to the paternal essence; if the paternal energy is robust, the child's posterior fontanelle will be firm and nourishing. Conversely, if the father's energy is insufficient, due to excessive desire for drunkenness, the child’s posterior fontanelle will be soft and not durable, leading to a shorter life. If both parents are weak, their offspring will also have shortened lives. In such cases, the parents themselves may struggle to reach their full lifespan. The anterior fontanelle is also known as the "Faith Gate"; in Daoist terms, it is the "Mud Ball," while the posterior fontanelle is referred to as the "Brain Gate." The center of the head is also known as the "Hundred Meetings." Hua Tuo provided detailed insights on facial diagnosis. The terms "fontanelle" and "faith" share the same pronunciation. When either the anterior or posterior fontanelles and the Hundred Meetings are open and weak, it is referred to as resolving skull issues.[4p]
    Yellowing of Hair

    Hair is the residue of blood. When a mother's blood and qi are plentiful, the hair is black, glossy, and vibrant; if the mother's blood is deficient, leaking, and failing, with menstrual irregularities, excessive indulgence in wine and lust, or if there are issues from the womb, the child's hair becomes yellow, dry, and brittle, leading to sores and boils.

    Headache Relief

    The kidneys govern the bone marrow, the spine is the pathway of the marrow, and the brain is the sea of marrow. The liver vessels and kidney vessels flow internally through the spine and converge in the brain. Hence, conditions affecting the head and pain in the spine are illnesses caused by wind-heat of the liver and kidneys, passed from mother to child. There are two types of headache relief: one occurs shortly after birth with the skull sutures split, the scalp appearing tight and glossy; this is due to heat in the marrow. The other occurs five to six months after birth when the fontanelle closes and then reopens; children of this situation are often difficult to nurture. For illnesses of wind-heat in the kidneys and liver, it is advisable to use a modified Qingpian pill to treat it, as it is to relieve the child. The Qingpian pill should be combined with equal parts of rhubarb, scutellaria, and coptis, ground into powder, formed into honey pills, and taken. The eight ingredients for relieving headaches include heat and additional components. Bind with cotton, including cyperus and white skullcap.[5p]
    Swelling of the Fontanel

    Due to irregular feeding, hunger and fullness arise, cold and heat accumulate, and the spleen's energy surges upwards. This results in swelling of the fontanel, varying in severity, and it's difficult to treat with the interplay of wind and heat. The treatment should focus on reducing heat and dispelling wind, with the use of the "Xie Qing Wan" for notable effects.

    Sunken Fontanel

    Prolonged diarrhea leads to deficiency of qi and blood, which cannot support the ascending vital energy. Fry dog spine and grind it into a fine powder, mix with egg white, and taking it will lead to recovery. The medicine should consist of "Shen Ling Bai Zhu San," which will alleviate the sunken fontanel effectively.

    Brain Sores

    Brain sores occur shortly after birth in infants, manifesting as wounds forming crusts resembling overturned pancakes, caused by wind and heat. It is advisable to enhance the "Xie Qing Wan" with additional ingredients like Vitex negundo and fried burdock fruit.

    Delayed Hair Growth

    Hair is the surplus of blood and a sprout of the kidneys. If a child’s hair does not grow for a long time, and when it does, it is sparse and not black, this is due to insufficient kidney energy and blood. The "Di Huang Wan" is the prescribed remedy.[6p]
    Secrets of Infant Care (Ming Dynasty, Wan Quan)

    Resolving Head Issues

    A child is inherently weak and timid; if the vital energy from the fetus is insufficient, the spirit becomes lacking, resulting in excessive white in the eyes, and the skull appears unlocked, with a pale complexion. Such children are difficult to raise and often do not live beyond eighteen years. If one restrains sexual desires, they may live a little longer but still not surpass forty days.

    There are two types of unlocked skulls: one that gradually opens after birth due to weak fetal energy and insufficient kidney strength. If it closes and then reopens, there may be cracks from the skull to the glabella, which can open slightly. If there are four cracks forming sutures, these are all indications of an unlocked skull. If the child is weak after an illness, with kidney deficiency causing water to overpower fire, the fiery essence rises, resulting in heat in the marrow; when the marrow is hot, it unlocks and the skull separates again. For those with kidney deficiency, it is advisable to take Rehmannia Pills to replenish the kidney's insufficiency, along with "Tiaoyuan Decoction" and "Shiquandabu Decoction" for both mother and child to strengthen the spleen and stomach, gradually solidifying energy and blood so that the skull naturally closes.

    For heat in the marrow, it is recommended to take Tongsheng Powder in pill form, avoiding nitrate; external application of the sealing method on the head may also help, or using a soft cloth to tightly bind it. Covering with a cloth for an extended period can also lead to a good outcome.

    Additionally, some children have heads that grow larger after birth, with red scalp and small eyes; this is known as "brain sore." It results from the heat and toxic energy of the parents contained in the kidneys, which then rises to the brain, causing the head to enlarge and become red. Such conditions are difficult to treat and typically do not extend beyond eighteen years. If the child, before turning one, develops sores and crusts all over the head, experiencing itchiness and pain, leading to inconsolable crying day and night, this too is hard to manage. It is advisable to administer the previously mentioned "苦参丸" (Bitter Herb Pills) and apply "松皮散" (Pine Bark Powder).[7p]
    Swelling and Depression of the Fontanel

    The prescription for swelling and depression of the fontanel states: "Excessive heat causes swelling, while deficient heat causes depression." Swelling at the fontanel means the bone protrudes and swells upward. The classics say: "Excessive heat causes swelling, due to the evil fire rising, causing the clear and bright qi to rise without descending." There are two signs: if the swelling is firm to the touch, this means there is a cold evil on the surface, closing the pores, preventing cold and heat from escaping, which is what is meant by "qi rushing up causes firmness." In this case, one should use the Rising Yang Disperse Fire Decoction; this will resolve the stagnation. If the swelling feels soft and floating upon touch, this indicates accumulated heat within, steaming upward, referred to as "qi rushing up causes softness." The use of a medicinal pill made of alcohol and Xuanwu should be employed to suppress this condition. When an outbreak occurs, the illness will stop immediately.

    Scalp Sores

    For sores on the scalp, do not allow them to become ulcers due to skin breakdown, resulting in pus that does not dry, with hair stuck together and lice breeding within. Scratching due to itching will lead to chronic conditions, resulting in leprosy. First, eliminate the lice by washing with a decoction of Acorus calamus, which will kill all the lice; let it dry, then mix mercury and fine powder in a bowl, grinding them together, and adding some saliva to moisten. Use your finger to dab the medicine onto the sores and within the hair. Once the lice are removed, apply a suitable amount of smoke from the autumn cowhide mixture with rosin, ground into a fine powder, and mixed with a little light powder and realgar, then heated and applied to the affected areas. For soft sores on the scalp that do not heal over time, applying the Purple Gold Pill will be effective.[8p]
    Delayed Hair Growth

    The presence of hair on the head is like the presence of grass and trees on a mountain. Hair is an excess of blood, and its abundance or scarcity depends on the richness or depletion of blood. The hexagram of Kan represents blood; blood is the essence of the kidneys, and hair is a sprout of the kidneys, which is why it is black in color. If a child's hair does not grow for a long time or is not black when it does, this indicates kidney deficiency. It is advisable to use the Rehmannia Glutinosa Pill as treatment. After a serious illness, if the hair appears in tufts or is sparse, this indicates insufficient body fluids, resulting from malnourishment. It is recommended to use the Gathered Holy Powder as treatment.

    Depressed Fontanelle

    A depressed fontanelle refers to the depression of the fontanelle creating a pit. There are two signs: the classics say that a depression indicates deficient energy. After a serious illness, when body fluids are insufficient, and true energy sinks down creating a pit, one should greatly replenish original energy and use the Regulate Original Decoction with Cimicifuga. If there is deficiency in the spleen and stomach, leading to a reduced appetite, and as the spleen governs the muscles, when the flesh decreases and the skin becomes thin, the fontanelle may appear protruding, which is not a true depression. In this case, one should take the Fat Baby Pill or Ginseng and Poria Powder to nourish the spleen and stomach so that appetite returns, the muscles become balanced, and the fontanelle no longer protrudes.[9p]

    Concerns Regarding Head Deformities and Neck Weakness

    Head Deformities

    After a hundred days, if the head is flattened, the "Book on Nurturing Young Hearts" states that the condition is more serious than a skull indentation; this is a great void, and there is virtually no chance of survival. One must not see this as a disease but rather a failure of the parents. When a newborn’s skull is not fused, one should use a soft pillow made of mung beans and adjust it frequently; do not allow the head to rest on just one side, for then the skull will surely align properly. If after this the occipital bone is still sunk in, it is due to prolonged sleeping in one position. If it becomes difficult to nurture the child and the skull shows fractures and unevenness, it is not a sign of longevity.

    Neck Weakness

    If the head is tilted backward, it indicates a weak neck. The neck is the stem of the head, also known as the Heavenly Pillar Bone. A weak neck signifies that the Heavenly Pillar Bone cannot maintain the head, causing it to tilt forward, backward, or sideways—a serious condition. The symptoms can be twofold: if a newborn has a weak neck right from birth, it results from insufficient prenatal nourishment and weak kidney energy. The kidneys regulate the bones, while the liver regulates the tendons; when tendons don’t support the bones, fractures can occur, causing the mother to deplete the child's vitality. Such a child is difficult to nurture, rarely living beyond forty years. With kidney energy being weak, it is advisable to use Rehmannia Pills with added Angelica and Dipsacus for treatment. In cases where weakness arises after a severe illness, leading to an inability to hold up the head, it is a sign of deficient blood and energy, and one should take the Totally Restorative Decoction with honey pills. The texts state: the head is the dwelling of clarity and brightness. If the head is tilted or misaligned, the spirit will depart. Generally, individuals suffering from severe illness showing this symptom are difficult to treat.[10p]
    Kānyǎn (Malnutrition-related Eye Condition)

    This condition is often due to excessive consumption of rich and spicy foods, which accumulates heat and leads to the spleen and stomach being impaired. This causes the eyes to become red and watering, the pupils to develop spots, and eventually to appear white over time, necessitating prompt treatment; otherwise, it may result in chronic disease. Initially, administer a heat-clearing drink, and then follow with Wǔgān Wán (Five Malnutrition Pills).

    Jiělú (Head Unclosed Condition)

    Zhongyang states that the condition of the head being unclosed at birth is due to insufficient kidney energy, which affects the formation of the head, leading to a tendency towards smiling less. Additionally, if the whites of the eyes are prominent and the body is thin, it indicates a disposition towards worry and little joy. I have observed this in cases of kidney deficiency. Yang states: for older infants whose cranial sutures remain open and unjoined, the kidneys govern the marrow, and the brain is considered the sea of marrow; when kidney energy is lacking, the brain and marrow are insufficient, resulting in the inability of the skull to close. A person deficient in brain marrow is like a tree without roots; generally, those with this condition will not survive long. In some cases, it takes several years to become incapacitated. If this condition is present, one should not remain passive; it is advisable to use Qiánshì Dìhuáng Wán (Qian's Rehmannia Pills) and also to prepare a fine powder of Nánxīng (Arisaema), mix it with rice vinegar, and apply it heated on scarlet silk, which is also an effective method. Applying Baiziren San (Platycladus Seed Powder) or Sanxin San (Three Aromatic Powder) is particularly excellent.[11p]
    Yuan Xian and Yuan Tian

    Yuan Xian refers to the condition where the top of the head sinks. It is primarily caused by internal heat in the organs, leading to thirst and excessive drinking. This, in turn, results in diarrhea, and over time, the blood and energy become weak, unable to nourish the brain marrow. Hence, the top of the head sinks like a pit, not appearing full. To treat this, bone powder from a dog’s skull, roasted to a yellow powder, is mixed with chicken egg white and applied.

    Yuan Tian refers to swelling or protrusion at the top of the head. The spleen governs the muscles, and irregularities in nourishment—be it overfeeding or underfeeding, hot or cold—can lead to imbalances in the internal organs. This causes energy to surge upwards, leading to swelling and protrusion of the head, which appears raised like a pile. When cold energy surges, it is hard and firm, while when hot energy surges, it is soft. If it is cold, apply warmth; if hot, apply cooling. The treatment dosage should be adjusted accordingly.

    For children, if liver energy is excessive, or when wind-heat attacks, the condition may similarly arise. This condition is not easily resolved. For heat symptoms, use a large Lianqiao powder to dispel it; if it’s a surface heat symptom, use Chaihu powder. There is also Fengyuan powder to cover it.

    According to the theory, if a child’s stomach energy is balanced, the brain marrow will be full and the top of the head will gradually flatten. If the stomach is heated, it steams the internal organs, causing thirst and leading to diarrhea, which blocks heat in the organs. This weakens the blood and energy, hence the top of the head sinks. The "Sheng Ji Jing" recommends using Danggui powder and Dihuang pills for treatment.[12p]
    Eye Conditions and Treatments

    If the eyes are red, it indicates heat in the heart; treat with "Da Chi San". If they are light red, it suggests deficiency heat in the heart; use "Sheng Xi San". If the eyes appear green, it indicates liver heat; treat with "Xie Qing Wan". If the color is pale, it should be replenished. If yellow, it suggests spleen heat; use "Xie Huang San". If there is no luster in the eyes, it indicates kidney deficiency; treat with "Di Huang Wan". According to the "Long Mu Lun", when young children have crossed eyes, it is often due to accidents causing injury to the head, resulting in shock to the liver, leading to the condition. For this, "Niu Huang Wan" is recommended. For bloodshot eyes, take "Sheng Shu Di Huang San", as it promotes blood circulation. For heat toxins, use "Xiao Fang Feng Tang"; for wind toxins, use "Xiao Liu Qi Yin"; and for accumulated toxins, "Xiao Ju Hua Gao" is appropriate. If there are rashes affecting the eyes, "Jue Ming San" or "Mi Meng Hua San" is recommended. Additionally, "Xi Jiao San" or "Shi Nan San" can also be effective. Sometimes after vomiting or diarrhea, the eyes may appear covered, or if there are rashes affecting the eyes, causing distress, if there are various symptoms leading to a loss of luster in the eyes, it can be difficult to treat.[13p]

    Ear Disease

    The ear is a manifestation of the kidney. In children, when the kidney energy is abundant, the heat rises and impacts the ear, causing fluids to stagnate and transform into pus or other substances. Additionally, when water from bathing enters the ear, the humidity stays and interacts with the blood energy, brewing heat, which can also cause ear pus. If it persists without healing, it may eventually lead to deafness. Long Gu San is indicated for this condition.

    Moreover, the Tang family has identified five types of ear discharge. The first type, "yellow pus ear," usually has yellow pus discharging; the second type, "red pus ear," typically has red pus; the third type, "white pus ear," consistently has white pus; the fourth type, "foul ear," has a stinky discharge from within; and the fifth type, "hollow ear," presents with a hollow, ringing sound and sometimes discharges clear pus. However, all five conditions stem from the same source: wind and water entering the ear, leading to internal accumulation of heat. If not treated promptly, it may result in deafness. Treatments such as Yan Zhi Gao and others, along with medications to resolve phlegm and reduce heat, can result in recovery.[14p]
    Nasal Illness

    For infants, on the third day, fifth day, sixth morning, or in the middle of a month, if they suddenly have nasal congestion and cannot suckle or breathe through the mouth, this often occurs when the wet nurse is asleep, and the exhalation from her nose blows onto the child. Alternatively, washing with water, whether warm or cold, without avoiding wind and cold can cause nasal congestion in the child. It is advisable to apply a nasal opening ointment and use dispersing medicine. If there are signs of fright and heat, peppermint powder can be taken, which is also good for the living.

    There is also nosebleed, which occurs when heat attacks the qi and affects the blood. The lungs control the skin and hair of the entire body, and the mouth opens the cavities to the nose. If cold first enters the skin and then attacks the qi forming heat, this heat then affects the blood. When the blood becomes heated and behaves erratically, it releases from the nose, which is called a nosebleed. If sweating does not occur and dryness and wheezing in the nose persist, it can lead to a nosebleed. Treatment methods follow traditional formulas and adjust dosages slightly. Huangqin Decoction and Rhinoceros Horn and Rehmannia Decoction are the main treatments. Boiled fresh Rehmannia and reed roots are especially effective. For nosebleeds, Huangqin Decoction is the main treatment. Qingfei Drink treats the nose (covering inner pests) and cools the diaphragm.[15p]
    Essentials of Infant Care

    The kidneys govern the bones. When kidney energy is sufficient, the brain's marrow fills, and the fontanel closes early; the bones and vessels flourish, and teeth emerge early. When kidney energy is weak, the brain's marrow is deficient, and the fontanel does not close. This occurs due to insufficient essence and blood from the parents, and it is advisable to use Rehmannia Pills for supplementation. If the child is still nursing, the mother should also supplement to harmonize and nourish the spleen and kidneys. Additionally, this condition may arise from inherent weakness in kidney energy and improper nursing, leading to deficiency in the spleen and stomach, which would also require the use of the Qi-Increasing Decoction. In cases of diarrhea with weak qi and blood, where the spleen and stomach cannot provide nourishment, the same approach applies. If the hands and feet are cold, add ginger and cinnamon to the previous decoction; if there is no response, indicating severe cold deficiency, urgently add Aconite. Delays may lead to irreparable consequences.[16p]
    Ear Disorders

    The ear is the aperture of the heart and kidneys, and it corresponds to the liver and gallbladder. The heart and kidneys govern internal Essence and blood deficiency, while the liver and gallbladder are associated with external conditions of excess wind and heat. Conditions such as deafness or tinnitus are due to congenital deficiency; whereas symptoms like fullness, pain, or itch with pus are caused by pathogenic factors. For congenital insufficiency, one should use Liu Wei Di Huang Wan. For excess wind-heat in the liver channel, Cha Hu Qing Gan San is recommended. If due to blood dryness, Zhi Zi Qing Gan San should be used; if ineffective, it can be supplemented with Liu Wei Wan and intermittently combined with Jiu Wei Lu Huo Wan. If caused by kidney and liver heat, Liu Wei Wan should be taken in the morning, and Lu Huo Wan in the evening. For food accumulation leading to internal heat, Si Wei Fei Er Wan is indicated. If it is caused by excess heat from food consumed by a nursing mother, Jia Wei Qing Wei San should be added. If due to spleen stagnation, add Jia Wei Gui Pi Tang. If anger heat in the liver channel is the cause, Jia Wei Xiao Yao San is appropriate. All the above should be taken by the nursing mother, with a small amount given to the child. One should not focus solely on treating the external symptoms, as this can also block the ear channel, leading to other disorders, prolonged retention leading to lifelong deafness. Be cautious![17p]
    Vision Diagnosis

    The scripture states: The eyes are the essence of the five organs and six bowels, constantly nourished by the spirit and soul. They are the main control of the spirit and qi. It is also said that all channels are connected to the eyes; the eyes obtain blood to see. The essence and qi from the five organs and six bowels flow upward to nourish the eyes. Therefore, the white part of the eye corresponds to the lungs, the black part to the liver, the pupil to the kidneys, the upper and lower eyelids to the spleen, the inner canthus to the heart, and the outer canthus to the bladder. Each of the five organs corresponds to a color, each having its own functions. The heart governs red; if red is excessive, it indicates heart fire, treated with a dispersing formula for red. If red is slight, it indicates heart deficiency heat, treated with a nourishing formula containing rhinoceros horn. The liver governs green; if green is excessive, it indicates liver heat, treated with a cooling formula for green. If it is pale green, it indicates liver deficiency, treated with a formula of Rehmannia. The spleen governs yellow; if yellow is excessive, it indicates spleen heat, treated with a cooling formula for yellow. If it is pale yellow, it indicates spleen deficiency, treated with a replenishing formula. If the eyes lack brightness and the white part is dark with little clarity, it indicates deficiency of both liver and kidneys, treated with a formula of Rehmannia combined with deer antler. If vision is clear by day but lost by night, it results from weakened yang qi, and in the presence of strong yin at night, the yang weakens further, resulting in inability to see, treated with a harmonizing and stomach nourishing decoction. If there are red channels with opacities moving from top to bottom, it belongs to the Foot Taiyang channel, treated with Dongyuan's selected extraordinary decoction; if moving from bottom to top, it belongs to the Foot Yangming channel, treated with a formula for regulating qi. The opacity membranes indicate internal wind-heat. If the pathogenic qi is unsettled, it is called hot opacity and floats on the surface; if the pathogenic qi is settled, it is called water opacity and sinks within; if the pathogenic qi is deep, it is called trapped opacity. It is advisable to use medicines that uplift and dispel the opacity.[18p]
    If there are black and white spots appearing under the upper eyelid, it relates to cold water of the sun; if they progress from the outside inwards, it pertains to the wind and heat of the lesser yang; if they appear green from the bottom upwards, it is related to the foot yangming and diseases of the lungs and kidneys. For cataracts, this is caused by the upward surge of liver fire and damp heat, with deficiency in the spleen failing to raise clear qi, leading to white spots, inability to open the eyelids, and tears that resemble paste, which over time can produce pus and damage the eyes. One should use the Remedies to Enhance Qi and Brighten Vision, the Poria Decoction to Drain Dampness, and the Four Flavor Fattening Pills. If the eyes cannot open, it may be due to irregular intake of dairy and food, or excessive consumption of cold medicines, causing the yang qi to sink and failing to rise, hence the inability to open the eyes; this requires the Bupleurum Decoction to Restore Life. If there is deficiency in stomach qi, and the eyelashes lack strength, causing an inability to open, one should use the Decoction to Tonify the Middle and Augment Qi. If there is sudden redness, swelling, and pain, this indicates an exuberance of liver fire; the Longdancao Decoction to Drain the Liver should be employed.[19p]
    For those who have watery eyes and feel shy in the light, it is due to accumulated heat in the liver and heart; use Shengxi San. There are also cases of liver and kidney deficiency heat; for these, use Dihuang Wan. If the eyes are afflicted by wind and feel rotten, it is due to accumulated heat in the diaphragm; use Qingwei San. If there is frequent itching, it indicates the presence of pus and maggots; apply Zisu Gao. If the eyelashes are entangled, it is due to wind-heat in the liver channel; use Chaihu Qinggan San. If there is yellowing of the lower eyes accompanied by strong fever, constipation, lack of appetite, flushed face, and closed eyes, this is caused by the mother’s heat and toxins during pregnancy; the child should take Xiehuang San and the mother Dihuang Wan. If the breastfeeding mother has accumulated heat causing the child’s yellowing eyes, the mother should take Qingwei San. If the limbs, face, and nails are all yellow, and the urine is the color of house dust, it is difficult to treat. Additionally, if there are residual toxins from measles affecting the eyes, it indicates kidney and liver deficiency; use Ziyin Shenqi Wan.     Nasal Congestion and Nosebleed

    The Physician Chao stated: The nose is the opening of the lungs, and the skin and pores are primarily linked to the lungs. If the illness has lasted a long time and the original qi is depleted, with reduced appetite, fever, dry mouth, drinking soup, vomiting, diarrhea, cold sensitivity in the limbs, and sleeping with open eyes, this indicates that both the form and sickness are deficient and the main focus should be on replenishing the righteous qi.[21p]
    Discussion on the Fontanel

    The "Sutra on the Fontanel" states: If the fontanel has not closed, the sinews and bones will be soft and weak. If the fontanel shows blue veins, it signifies a weak and un-nourished pulse. If the fontanel is constantly sunken, it leads to frequent diarrhea. If the fontanel is protruding, wind diseases will not cease. If the fontanel remains cold for a long time, it causes clear vomiting and diarrhea. If the fontanel is soft and slack, seizures from dizziness are unavoidable. If the fontanel is flat and depressed, diarrhea may easily occur. If the fontanel is elongated, it predisposes to death from wind. If the fontanel connects with the forehead, it is easy to be startled into convulsions. If the fontanel is incomplete, there will be fear of heat and aversion to cold. If the fontanel closes slowly, the prenatal energy may be inadequate. If the fontanel has frequent movements, it indicates confusion of the spirit and weakness of energy. If the fontanel is wide, it leads to numerous illnesses and suffering. The fontanel is the gateway of the spirit and the key to the pathways of the body. It connects the upper and lower regions and links all important points. The seven orifices should be open, as are those of the five organs. The palace of the mud ball is the cavity of the soul and spirit. When energy is strong, it is closed; when energy is weak, it is open. This is due to growth; closure cannot be neglected. Physicians, upon examination, should discern the situation and decide on treatment. Medications must be employed cautiously. If the fontanel is wide and the illness is severe, the fear is that treatment may be difficult, necessitating caution.[22p]

    Residual Toxicity from Smallpox

    Smallpox is the most severe of poisons, due to the accumulation of malevolent toxins since birth. In ancient times, it was called the "Hundred-Year Sore," as it is something that no one can avoid throughout their century of life. Once it manifests, the pure and harmonious vital energy of the body's channels and meridians is disturbed, resulting in a significant depletion of the righteous qi, allowing evil influences to take hold, each manifesting as various diseases based on what has been transgressed. Moreover, the eye, which is the clearest and most pure, is connected to the liver and gallbladder. The liver and gallbladder are the repositories of purity, where good and evil cannot coexist. When one's body is exposed to impure evils, it leads to a loss of the source of nourishment for the eyes, making them susceptible to illness; this happens because individuals are unable to rescue themselves and instead inflict harm upon themselves.[32p]
    Some illnesses arise from excessive consumption of food when one is unwell, retaining too much warmth, mistakenly taking hot medications, or consuming too much sweet and sour food, leading to illness. Others may become ill after recovery from an ailment, due to deficiency, overeating spicy, dry, fatty foods, overexerting oneself with excessive visual strain or crying, and exposing oneself to wind, dust, smoke, and miasmas. There may be cases of internal symptoms causing blurred vision and tearing or external symptoms like red, inflamed star-like obstructions. Some may have residual pathogenic factors that lead to conditions like fat and yellow membranes, or corneal opacities, which can result in protruding eyes. Others may have milder saline manifestations like red threads or slight haziness that resolve on their own. The severity and nature of these conditions vary from person to person and should be treated based on the specific symptoms, as blindly adhering to one approach may cause adverse reactions.

    After experiencing smallpox, a person may feel reborn, yet different from usual. If any discomfort persists, it could cause lifelong harm. Therefore, those in this field should exercise caution. Generally, treating conditions early makes recovery easier with fewer complications; if delayed, even if there are no significant changes, blood and energy may congeal, making even straightforward cases harder to remedy. People today often assume that visual disorders following smallpox cannot be treated. However, if the pupil and gaze are not affected, there may still be a chance for recovery, even after a long time. It’s only when blood has solidified and symptoms of obstruction have developed that treatment becomes infeasible.

    Ni Zhongxian states that residual toxin from rashes is somewhat similar to illnesses from unregulated wind and heat, and should be primarily treated with antler horn powder. For less severe cases, reduce the use of nitrate and yellowrye. If the illness appears within twenty days, one should apply detoxifying and rash-resolving decoctions.[33p]

    Cranial Relief

    Discussion on Swollen and Sunken Fontanelle

    All newborns have a fontanelle, as their internal energy is not yet full, their bone marrow is not complete, and nourishment is insufficient. Internal organs rely on the spleen and stomach for nourishment. After birth, when the child is fed with grains, their internal energy is replenished and bone marrow matures, leading to the closing of the fontanelle once they can eat. The fontanelle is connected to the spleen and stomach. The "Seng Ji Jing" states that the fontanelle is connected to earth, which corresponds to the spleen and stomach. If a child has a swollen fontanelle, it is due to disharmony in the spleen and stomach, imbalance of hot and cold, angry crying when fed, or wheezing and coughing, leading to a reversal of Yin and Yang energy that causes the fontanelle to swell. It swells and feels soft with heat, and swells and feels hard with cold. A sunken fontanelle may result from diarrhea, frequent urination, past intake of cleansing medicines, inherent weak energy, or lingering other illnesses, all of which render the internal organs deficient and unable to nourish the fontanelle, hence causing it to sink. These are all severe conditions for children, and few manage to recover.[39p]
    On Various Head Diseases

    Soft boils that appear on a child's head are caused by the invasion of wind and cold, affecting the skin, lingering in the blood and qi, obstructing the meridians, and accumulating to form these boils, similar to those that arise on the body but located on the head. Initially, they appear red and swollen and hard; if the pathogen is mild, it may dissipate on its own. However, if the pathogen is severe, the swelling becomes red and painful, producing pus and blood. Due to the tightness of the scalp, it is often difficult to fully remove the pus when it becomes mature; there may be residual foul fluid that leads to recurrence or the emergence of new boils at the edges, resulting in continuous non-healing, often painfully abscessing, hence the name soft boils.

    For children with bald patches on the head, according to the Nine Worms theory: this is caused by pinworms interacting with wind pathogens, affecting the skin of the head, colliding with the blood and qi, and injuring the nourishing and protective aspects. The nourishing aspect relates to blood; when diseased, it leads to red baldness; the protective aspect relates to qi; when diseased, it causes white baldness. As the nourishing aspect is internal, it is more difficult for pathogens to affect it, hence cases of red baldness are rare; meanwhile, as the protective aspect is external, pathogens can easily invade, leading to more cases of white baldness.[40p]
    At first, it appears like spots of scabs, with flakes of skin on top. Gradually, it forms crusts, leading to wounds that ultimately result in nearly complete hair loss. If the crusts are scraped off, the wounds are filled with holes of varying sizes. There is pus that oozes out, and while there is no pain, there is an unbearable itch, indicating the presence of a "wind" insect. There is also a condition commonly called "ghost licking the head," where a child with a scalp sore is said to be licked by a ghost overnight, resulting in red crusts covering the head, sometimes referred to as "red baldness."

    The cause of a child's scalp sore is internal heat affecting the organs, which then rises to the head. Coupled with external wind and moisture, these factors combine, impacting the blood and qi, thereby leading to the sores, hence it is called scalp sores. This condition is distinct from bald sores. Bald sores can appear both white and red, with hard crusts covering the entire head. In contrast, scalp sores might only appear in one or two spots, lacking the whitish, hard, dry texture, often exuding pus and blood. Commonly referred to as "long scalp sores," these are known to occur when children fail to wash their hair properly.[41p]
    About Hair

    Those with a vigorous heart and spirit have clear forms and abundant hair; those with a timid heart have little to no hair growth, and if it does grow, it lacks color. The heart governs the blood, and hair is considered the surplus of blood; thus, timidity leads to prolonged absence of growth.

    Discussion on Diseases of the Ear

    When a child suddenly suffers from deafness or diminished hearing, it is due to the invasion of wind pathogens affecting the Hand Taiyang channel. The pathogen follows this channel and enters the ear; when the pathogen clashes with the correct energy, it causes stagnation and blockage, resulting in deafness and inability to hear sounds. In mild cases, it may result in diminished hearing, where the ear feels heavy, making it hard to distinguish faint sounds, while louder noises can still be heard.[42p]
    Ear Noises and Pain

    If a child experiences ringing or pain in the ears, it is due to the invasion of wind evil into the ears, which interferes with vital energy. If it collides with blood and qi, it results in ringing; if it affects the meridians, it leads to pain.

    Ear Swelling and Pus

    If a child has swelling or sores in the ears producing pus, it results from a combination of wind and dampness entering the ears, affecting the opposition between evil and vital energy, colliding with qi and blood, and damaging the meridians. If mild, it causes swelling; if severe, sores may develop. If bodily fluids accumulate and break down, pus and blood may emerge. Additionally, if water or tears enter the ears, obstructing vital energy, this too can lead to pus, commonly referred to as "tinnitus" or "purulent ear."

    Eye Diseases Discussion

    When a child has eye diseases, it is often due to excessive consumption of sweet and sour foods, generating internal heat and affecting the liver meridian, which manifests in the eyes. This may lead to redness, swelling, itching, or pain; excessive tearing; the presence of red veins; or the formation of membranes. If phlegm, dampness, and toxic qi invade the liver, causing its energy to become obstructed, then clarity is not achieved; hence, even if the pupils are intact, vision may be impaired, a condition termed "dimming vision." If one cannot see during the day, it is considered an evil affecting the yin of the meridians, known as "night blindness," akin to a bird that cannot see in the dark. Additionally, there can be eye obstructions caused by toxic qi covering the eyes, or liver heat impacting the eyes, which can also lead to membrane formation as a barrier.[43p]
    Discussion on Nasal Disorders

    The lung qi communicates with the nose. If the qi is not harmonized, it can be invaded by wind and cold, becoming stagnant in the nose, obstructing the fluids and causing mucus to congeal, resulting in blocked nasal passages, which is termed nasal obstruction. If wind and cold obstruct the blood qi, causing the formation of flesh-like obstructions, it is called nasal polyp. If wind and dampness interact, sores and purulent discharge may develop in the nose. If heat from the brain attacks the nose leading to dryness, or if sores and scabs form, they may be hard and devoid of purulent discharge.
    — From the "Young and Young Near Compilation" by Chen Zhi (Ming Dynasty)

    Nasal Collapse

    Nasal collapse occurs due to deficiency of kidney qi, leading to insufficient brain marrow, with damp heat ascending, causing the cranial sutures to separate and not align. It is advisable to use Di Huang Wan with deer antler and fried Baizhu. For those with qi deficiency and heat, the Four Gentlemen Decoction with fried Baizhu is recommended. The "Expanded Meaning" suggests treating nasal collapse with crab claws mixed with Rhizoma Bletillae, ground into a paste and applied to the crown.

    Nasal Depression

    Nasal depression occurs when qi and blood are both deficient and the original qi sinks. It is suitable to use the Middle-Qi Boosting Decoction; if the hands and feet are cold, add ginger, cassia, and even prepared aconite.

    Nasal Filling

    Nasal filling occurs due to deficiency of the spleen and stomach leading to a reversal of qi that ascends. There may also be spleen-stomach heat or damp heat present. In these cases, it is advisable to use Yigong San with fried Baizhu, Mu Xiang, and Viticis Fructus. If damp heat ascends, add Atractylodes.[44p]
    Dongyi Baojian [Joseon, Xu Jun]

    Nape Weakness

    Nape weakness refers to the Tianzhu bone being misplaced; it is advisable to use Jian Gu San and Sheng Jin San. When a child suffers from long-term malnutrition and has a weak body, or when the Tianzhu bone is displaced due to various illnesses, and the physician cannot identify it, this is known as five weaknesses. If a child has a soft neck due to wind, causing the head to tilt forward or backward, Tianzhu Wan and Wujia Pi San should be used; if due to wind-heat, it is appropriate to use Liang Gan Wan.

    Hair Not Growing

    Hair not growing is due to insufficient nourishment of qi and blood, failing to nourish the hair; it is advisable to take Congrong Wan.

    Fetal Disorders

    If a newborn shows a lack of quick eye movement when observing objects, and by age four or five the pupils are completely white and unclear, extending into old age without treatment, this is due to excessive heat received during gestation.

    Eyes Not Aligning

    If an infant’s eyes are misaligned, wanting to look east but seeing west, and shaking their head continually affects sight, this is due to the liver being disturbed by wind; it is advisable to take Niu Huang Wan.

    Eye Growths

    If growths appear on the eyelids, starting as large as a sesame seed and gradually growing like a bean, hanging down inside the eyelid, this is caused by wind-heat attacking the spleen channel; it is advisable to take Wutui San with modifications.

    Color Blindness

    If a fetus is affected by wind, leading to disharmony of the internal organs, resulting in vomiting yellow bile, both eyes being unclear in vision without any treatment method, this condition of color blindness refers to pupils being distinctly black and white but unable to see objects clearly.[45p]
    Kang Eye

    Children with kang-eye or strabismus may be blind or have retinas that do not see; they may also have pus. It is advisable to prepare liver pills and Longdan decoction.

      Thirty-six Remedies for Plastering the Neck

    For the first remedy: equal parts of Aconitum (Caowu) and red beans (Chixiaodou). Grind to a powder, mix with ginger juice, apply to cloth, and plaster on the neck to promptly alleviate symptoms.

    For the second remedy: Ji's neck plaster for children. It treats heat in the liver and coolness in the gallbladder, where the head and neck are soft and drooping. Ingredients include one qian each of Chuanwu, cinnamon (Rougui), mustard seeds (Yuntaizi), southern star (Nansxing), and castor seeds (Bimozi), along with one qian of fried yellow ochre. Grind the ingredients finely. Use one whole garlic, cook until soft, peel, and grind in a mortar, mixing thoroughly with the medicine. Use one qian of the mixture, blend it with rice vinegar, and apply to the neck for about a day.

    For the third remedy: Ji's wolf poison pills. This treats heat in the gallbladder and liver wind in children, especially when presenting with an upside-down neck. It is recommended to take this medicine along with the plaster mentioned above. For the ingredients: wolf poison soaked and roasted, white and large Aconitum (Bai Fuzi and Da Fuzi), Tianma, Fangfeng, Qianghuo, each one fen; one qian each of cinnabar and earthworm (Dilong) cleaned of soil; half a word of musk. Grind to a fine powder, mix into pills with medicinal liquor that is thick, about the size of a small bean. Take seven to fifteen pills with black bean and mint soup, with a drop of liquor to swallow down.

    For the fourth remedy: Jade Dew Drink. This treats the swelling and redness in the throat of children, as well as cheek redness, dry throat, body heat, and headaches. Use one liang each of cold water stone (Han shuishi) with fine veins that can be crushed, and gypsum (Shigao), which is pure white, hard, and has walls. Add three qian of dried licorice (Gancao) dried in the shade or baked by fire. Grind all ingredients except the first two into a fine powder. Use half a qian to one qian, mixed with warm water as needed, or with wheat winter soup (Maidong Tang).[53p]
    Fangfeng Decoction: Treats the same conditions.
    Fangfeng, Qianghuo, and Zhishi each 250 grams; Chuanxiong, roasted Gan-Cao, and stewed Dahuang each 25 grams. Grind them into a fine powder. Take three pinches each time, boiled with ginger and jujube.

    Jinye Pill: For children with cold stomach, spleen obstruction, extreme vomiting and diarrhea, leading to a sunken fontanelle. Use ten taels of sulfur, finely ground and placed in a magnetic container. Seal with eight parts water and red stone resin, reinforced with salty mud, and sun-dry. Bury a small jar full of water, place the container on top, seal again with salty mud, and calcine with charcoal for three days and nights. After cooling, take out and grind into a fine powder. Each time take two taels, consumed with ginger soup.

    Guzhen Decoction: Treats the same conditions.
    Ren Shen (ginseng) without its husk, Fu Zi (prepared Aconite) soaked and split, without skin; Bai Fu Ling (white Poria) without skin; Bai Zhu (white Atractylodes) each 25 grams; Shan Yao (Chinese yam) without black skin; Huang Qi (Astragalus) honey-water roasted; Rou Gui (cinnamon) without rough bark; Gan Cao (licorice) wrapped in damp paper, stewed through, each 25 grams. Grind the ingredients and take two taels each time, boiled in one cup of water with three slices of ginger and one jujube, cooked down to seven parts, taken warm on an empty stomach or at any time.[54p]
    Dalianqiao Decoction: Treats children's internal heat conditions, causing the fontanel to bulge.

Grind finely; each dose is five qian, mix with one zhong of water, boil down to five-fifths, take after meals.

    Chaihu Powder: Treats children's external heat conditions, causing swelling of the forehead.

    Ingredients: Tian Nanshen, Fuzi—each equal parts.

    Tong Sheng San (from "Zheng Zhi Zhun Sheng")
    To treat children's marrow heat and relieve the scalp, for smallpox invading the eyes and causing membranes to form. Use white chrysanthemum; if unavailable, substitute with sweet chrysanthemum, but white chrysanthemum is preferred. Also, use soybean pod skins and the roots of valley herb, each one tael.     Wash and dry red and blue flowers and prepare equal amounts of yellow berberine; half amounts of dried yellow qin and fishbone. Grind all four ingredients together into a fine powder, then use half a liang of finely ground musk with water. Mix everything well, then wrap in cotton and place inside the ear, replacing it twice daily.

    Prepare equal amounts of peeled and processed aconite and calamus, and use them to plug the ear.[76p]

    Formulas

    Lifesaving Eye Drops: To remove cloudiness and alleviate pain.

    • Ingredients: 2 qian of Angelica, 2 qian of Huanglian, 2.5 qian of Fangfeng, 0.5 qian of Xixin, 1 qian of Licorice.
    • Preparation: Add these to 1 large bowl of water, boil with gentle fire until it does not disperse in water; then add a small amount of prepared honey for use.

    Thousand Gold Liver Supplement Powder: For loss of vision.

    • Ingredients: 1 lamb’s liver (cleaned and thinly sliced), dried over a new tile, 0.5 qian of Jue Ming Zi, and 1 he of Polygala, boiled until fragrant.
    • Preparation: Grind into powder, take 1 pinch each time, twice daily; efficacy noted over time.

    Fundamental Formula: For obstruction and cloudy membrane causing vision blockage due to cold water at the Taiyang point.

    • Ingredients: 1 liang each of Fangfeng and Bai Jizhi, 2.5 qian of Qiang Huo, 3 liang of sweet chrysanthemum.
    • Preparation: Grind into powder, take 2 qian with a little salt, consumed with boiling water.

    Lifesaving Antelope Horn Powder: For long-term ice blindness.

    • Ingredients: Equal parts of Antelope Horn, Sheng Ma, and Xixin, half the amount of Licorice.
    • Preparation: Grind into powder; form half into pills the size of a tung seed (5 to 70 pills per dose); the other half boiled in water for taking with pills. Also used for treating opacity caused by dampness. If heat and yin deficiency are present, it can be used with the Immortal's Cloud-Dispersing Pills.[87p]
      Dongyuan Buyang Decoction is used to treat conditions in which yang cannot overcome yin, leading to an excess of yin and a deficiency of yang. This imbalance results in obstruction of the nine orifices, causing blue and white cataracts to appear at the corners of the eyes. The yin obstructs the flow of yang from the foot Taiyang and Shaoyin meridians, preventing it from ascending to the eyes, hence the internal blockage of blue cataracts. It is important to supplement the yang first and then drain the fire of the foot Jueyin from the foot Taiyin meridian, rooted in the yang.

    The Neijing states: When yin is excessive and yang is deficient, one should first supplement yang and then drain yin. Take Shengyang Decoction on an empty stomach daily, and before bed, take a draining yin pill. Anticipate adjustments and nurturing of the body’s energy, maintaining equilibrium of body energy and clarity of external conditions while taking this decoction. This will help to supplement yang, allowing it to rise and flow to the end of the liver meridian, thus benefiting the open orifices of the eyes.

    The ingredients include: Qianghuo, Duhuo, Danggui (washed and dried in wine), Licorice stalks, Shudihuang, Ren Shen, Huangqi, Baizhu, each one tael; Zexie and Ju Hong, each half a tael; Shengdi, Bai Fu Ling, and Zhimu, each three qian; Chaihu two taels; Fangfeng and Baishao, each five qian; and Rougui one qian.

    Prepare five qian for each dose, decocting with water and taking it on an empty stomach. Once the medicinal effect has been fully achieved, then one may eat and drink.[88p]

    For the Pig Gallbladder and Coptis Pills:
    This treats children's eye conditions with white membranes covering the eyes, particularly when other medicines have failed.

    Ingredients include equal parts of:

    • Hu Huanglian (胡黄连),
    • Realgar (雄黄),
    • Night shining sand (夜明砂) finely ground.

    Several pig gallbladders and a small amount of musk (麝香) not cooked with the gall.

    Grind together the powders using the pig gall juice to adjust the consistency. Pack this mixture into the gall bladder, tightly secured with thread, and boil in rice wash water for five to seven boils. Remove and cool. Grind the musk finely in a mortar and then combine with the medicinal powder, omitting the gall bladder. Form small pills the size of a hemp seed, taking ten pills per dose, increasing up to fifteen for larger patients, swallowed with rice drink. If liver qi is strong, use aged rice drink instead.

    The world traditionally recognizes Cao Zhuo powder for treating eye conditions.

    For the Cao Zhuo powder, use four taels of Cao Zhuo, soaked in rice wash, sliced, and roasted. This is ground into a fine powder. Take two taels of pig liver, opened and mixed with the powder inside, bound with hemp, combined with one he of millet and one bowl of water, then cooked in a sand pot until done and used to steam the eyes. Wait until warm, and take three qian before lying down; it is highly effective.

    For pig hoof shell powder, which treats children's rashes affecting the eyes: take two taels of pig hoof shell, and burn in salt mud until charred and ground to a powder. Remove soil from cicada shells and grind them into powder. Additionally, one tael of antelope horn should be ground into a fine powder.

    Mix the previous two ingredients and add one part of ground antelope horn. Each time, use a character's worth, with children over a hundred days old taking half a qian, and those over three years taking three qian, mixed with fresh or warm water, three to four times a day and one or two times at night. Treatment becomes difficult after a year.

    Another prescription, for ear treatment, uses one qian of cinnabar and eight fen of powder frost, ground into a fine powder and stirred with a little water. Use a spoon to drop one or two points into the ear. Additionally, use: white chrysanthemum, bean skin, valley herb, and night shining sand, ground into a powder.

    Boil these four ingredients into a paste with half a bowl of rice wash, strain it, then add ten or more dried persimmons and continue cooking. Eat two or three daily and drink the boiled persimmon soup.

    Another formula treats children's rashes affecting the eyes.[101p]
    Fine powder of equal parts of vermilion, brain, mercury, and musk.

    The above four ingredients are ground into a fine powder and mixed with water, then dropped into the ear.

    Peppermint Decoction is used to treat nasal congestion in infants and to address conditions caused by fright and cold. The ingredients include half a tael of peppermint leaves, a tael each of Qianghuo, scorpion, licorice, and Ma Huang (with the stalks removed), as well as a tael and a half each of Jiangcan (silkworm, toasted and without silk), Tianzhu Huang, and Bai Fuzhi.     Xiao Feng San (Wind-Dispersing Powder) is used to treat various wind attacks manifesting as headache, neck stiffness, limb soreness, muscle twitching, dizziness, ear ringing, dry eyes leading to sleepiness, nasal congestion with frequent sneezing, skin numbness, itching, and for children with weak wind symptoms. The ingredients include Bai Fu Ling, Chuan Xiong, Qianghuo, JIng Jie flower spikes, Fang Feng, Huoxiang leaves, Bai Jiangcan (toasted), and cicada slough (cleaned of soil), combined with toasted licorice and Huopaliang ginger, and aged tangerine peel without white parts, each at one tael.     Tong Guan San
    For treating children's nasal congestion, convulsions due to fright, and blockage of the orifices, all caused by phlegm obstructing the central cavity, which results in stagnation in the hundred joints. The reason phlegm becomes obstructive is due to the accumulation of qi.

    Ingredients:

    • Equal parts of southern star (Nanxing) powder, one qian
    • A small amount of musk, one character
    • Soap pod (Zaojiao), slightly burned to retain its nature, two qian
    • Red centipede (Chihwugong) roasted, one piece
    • Dried silkworms (Jiangcan), stir-fried to remove silk and mouthparts, one qian

    Mix these into a fine powder. Use a little ginger juice to dampen the powder and apply it to the teeth; alternatively, use a utensil to drip two or three drops of the medicine, which should help with salivation. Apply to clear the nasal congestion in the child.

    Xinyigao (Magnolia Ointment)
    For treating nasal congestion.

    Ingredients:

    • One liang of magnolia leaves, washed and dried
    • Half a liang each of fine sage, wood mullein, white angelica, and wood fragrance, all ground into a fine powder
    • One fen of apricot kernels, soaked to remove the skin and point, and ground

    Combine these with two liang each of sheep marrow and pig lard, and mix all the ingredients in a stone vessel, simmering slowly to form a yellowish-red ointment. After cooling, mix in one qian each of dragon brain (Longnao) and musk, stirring thoroughly. Use a small amount to apply inside the nose. For infants still breastfeeding, if the nurse blows into the infant's congested nose, just apply it to the forehead.[110p]
    Congxian Gao from the Gong Family: Used for children aged three to five days, who have nasal congestion and are breathless, crying continuously while feeding. Use seven strips each of pig's tooth soapberry and other ingredients, ground and mixed with the soapberry powder to form a paste, which can be applied to the bridge of the nose for healing.

    Rhinoceros Horn and Rehmannia Decoction: Used for treating nosebleeds. Ingredients: one tael of rhinoceros horn powder, one tael of peony root, eight Qian of raw dry rehmannia, and seven Qian of red peony. Take one to two Qian per dose, boiled in water for consumption.

    Rehmannia Powder (Yang's Recipe): Treats heat in the spleen, lung obstruction, and nosebleeds. Equal parts of raw rehmannia, red peony, dong quai (Chinese angelica), and chuanxiong (Sichuan lovage). Each dose is two to three Qian, boiled in water, adding a little catkins. For spring and summer nosebleeds, add a little rehmannia juice and catkins. For autumn and winter nosebleeds, use a little plantago seed juice.

    Liujunzi Decoction: Treats nosebleeds in children. Ingredients are equal parts of ginseng, white atractylodes, poria, dried tangerine peel, pinellia, and licorice. Grind into powder, taking two Qian per dose, boiled in ginger and jujube water.

    Four Substances Decoction: Treats infants with a bloated head, nosebleeds, and red color between the chin. The ingredients are one Qian each of dong quai, chuanxiong, peony, gardenia, and cooked rehmannia. Brew in water for consumption.[111p]
    Wuling San: Treatment as described above.
    Red Poria, Red Peony each 5 fen; roasted Gardenia, Angelica each 3 fen; Licorice 2 fen. Use ten lampwick stems, decoct in water for consumption.

    Huangqi Shaoyao Decoction: Treats persistent nosebleeds over the years, with a sallow complexion and dry eyes, excessive tearing and hand numbness.
    Huangqi 3 liang; roasted Licorice, Asarum, Kudzu, and Qianghuo each 1 liang; fried Peony 1 liang. Take 3 qian at a time, decoct in water for consumption. Xue Ji states: These are mainly substances for the Taiyin and Yangming; however, prolonged blood deficiency leads to Yang deficiency, hence insufficient blood causes numbness. It eliminates false heat and manifests various syndromes, clearly not wind. This example of uplifting Yin and Yang.

    Maimendong Yinzi: Treats a child's lips turning white, prolonged nosebleeds that do not heal.
    Schisandra 10 grains; Maimendong without hearts, Huangqi each 1 qian; Angelica root, Ginseng, Shengdi Huang each 5 fen. Decoct in water for consumption.

    Mutong San [from "Shenghui Fang"]: Treats a child's fever with no nasal discharge, dry mouth, and heart agitation, restless sleep.
    Mutong, chopped; Maimendong without hearts, roasted; Chuan Shengma each 5 fen; Zhimu, roasted bitter almonds (with skin and tips removed), lightly fried until yellow; rhinoceros horn, roasted Licorice lightly charred, each 1 fen; three Zhisou seeds. Grind these ingredients into a coarse powder. Take 1 qian per dose, using a small cup of water, decoct until reduced to 5 points, strain, and adjust dosage according to the child's size, consuming warm without time restrictions.[112p]

    Long Nao San (from Sheng Hui Fang)
    This treats children's nasal issues, where they cannot smell scents or odors.
    Ingredients:

    • 0.5 qian of Long Nao, finely ground
    • 14 gourd stems
    • 30 red beans
    • 3 large stems of Huang Lian, trimmed

    Qing Fei Gao by Zhang Huan, for treating nasal diseases.

    Half a tael of melon stem, one piece of prepared aconite (peel and navel removed), one fen each of red beans, fine cinnamon, and licorice. Grind these ingredients into a fine powder, add one qian of dragon brain, mix well, and knead with honey to form pills. Wrap them in cotton and insert them inside the nose, adjusting to the size of the nostrils.

    There are two prescriptions: the first is suitable for those with heat, while the second is for those with cold.

    Tong Xin San Qian Jin Fang, for treating children's nasal congestion causing nasal polyps.

    One tael each of Tong Cao (ventilating herb) and fine cinnamon. Grind these two ingredients into powder, form pills as big as beans, wrap in cotton, and insert into the nose twice daily.

    Another prescription (same as in "Qian Jin Yi") for treating nasal polyps that obstruct breathing: moisten fine cinnamon in the mouth, bend the head and insert it into the nose, apply generously around the inner sides, and change it ten times a day. After twenty days, use one tael of Lingzhi seeds and half a tael of pine resin, grind and sift the two ingredients, wrap in thin cotton to form pills the size of jujube seeds, and insert into the nose five to six times a day.

    After twenty days, take two taels of high-quality Wu Bai Fan (white alum), mix it with pottery clay, and burn it in a kiln until the pottery is done, then grind and sift it. Mix with face grease to make pills the size of jujube seeds and insert into the nose five to six times a day. It’s important not to blend too quickly, and treatment should continue for twenty days for recovery. Be cautious to avoid exertion and hot foods, as well as garlic, for one hundred days.

    Another remedy for nasal polyps causing loss of smell.[114p]

    Used to treat children with red noses.

    Used for nasal congestion and excessive mucus.

    Chrysanthemum Powder (Shenghui’s Formula)
    Used for children suffering from cold wind injuries, with excessive mucus in the nose and mental dullness.
    One fen each of sweet chrysanthemum, baizhu (Atractylodes), Xixin, baizhu (white Poria), roasted licorice, fengfeng, and ginseng.
    Crush these ingredients coarsely into a powder. Each dose is one qian, taken with a small cup of water, adding a little fresh ginger, and decocted until reduced to one-fifth. Strain out the residue, and depending on the child’s size and condition, adjust the temperature and amount for consumption.[115p]
    Xiong Yao San [From "Wan Quan Fang"]

    For treating the same condition.

    siler root,
    ginseng,

    white poria,
    and honey-fried licorice.

    Acupuncture

    The "Thousand Golden Prescriptions" states: for children with an inwardly sunken fontanel, cauterize half an inch above and below the navel, as well as the tip of the tailbone; also perform one moxibustion on each foot's Taiyin point. The "Medical Guidelines" states: if the fontanel is not closed, moxibustion should be applied to the points half an inch above and below the navel with three applications, cauterizing before sores develop. The "Ancient and Modern Medical Compendium" states: for children with a sunken fontanel, perform moxibustion on the Shuifen point seven times, and avoid acupuncture. The Shuifen point is located one inch below the xiphoid process and one inch above the navel, corresponding to the lower orifice of the small intestine. This is responsible for separating clarity from turbidity; fluids enter the bladder, waste into the large intestine, hence the term 'water division.' Alternatively, if using acupuncture, a length of three-tenths can be applied, and five moxibustions are then needed. Changqiang is also named Qizhi Yinque and Juegu, located at the tip of the sacral spine, measured at three-tenths; it must be accessed by lying prone. The points of the foot's Shaoyin and Shaoyang converge with the Governing Vessel and branch off to connect with the Conception Vessel.[142p]
    The "Genji Qiwei" says: For treating children with squint who cannot see at night, moxibustion should be applied one inch inward from the big toe's nail at the horizontal white meat junction, using one large cone of moxa, about the size of a small wheat grain.

    The "Weisheng Baojian" says: For children with malnutrition-related eye issues, moxibustion should be applied at each of the He Gu points, using one large cone, about the size of a small wheat grain, located between the two bones at the base of the big and index fingers.

    The "Yixue Wangmu" says: For children with blurry vision due to milk nodules, moxibustion should be applied to two Zhong Yu points on the shoulder, each with one large cone, situated two inches from the spine at the inner edge of the shoulder blade.

    The "Gu Jin Yi Tong" says: For children aged three to five, if they suddenly develop a white film covering their pupils during spring and autumn, with unbearable pain, moxibustion should be applied to the Dazhui point with one large cone.

    If a child has variola affecting the eyes, moxibustion should be applied to two Dazhui points, located one and a half inches to either side beneath the first cervical vertebra.

    For children who are sensitive to light and have symptoms resembling a "blue blind," moxibustion should be applied to both Zhong Zhu points with one large cone, located in the depression at the base of the middle finger and the adjacent finger.

    For children with severe heat and wind causing eye pain, moxibustion should be applied to the head of the middle finger's first joint three times, known as the "fist tip."[143p]

    A child experiencing a nosebleed accompanied by thirst, wheezing, and a flushed face indicated heart fire damaging the lungs and metal element. I used the Ren Shen Ping Fei San along with Di Huang Wan, adding Wu Wei and Mai Men Dong, and the child was healed.

    A seven-year-old girl had a nasal polyp and applied a toxic medicine, which resulted in swelling and pain. I applied powdered Huang Lian, Gan Cao, and Huang Bai externally to relieve heat toxicity; then I used the Jia Wei Xiao Yao San to clear liver fire; I complemented this with Si Wei Fei Er Wan, and the child recovered.

    Another girl often had polyps in her nose and lower part that protruded out about three inches each time she used caustic drugs. I first treated her with Long Dan Cao Tang primarily, and added Jia Wei Xiao Yao San as a supplementary treatment, resulting in her recovery.[165p]
    A weak child has a penchant for eating soil, charcoal, and ashes. Later, he has trouble breathing through his nose, and after strictly taking cooling medicines, his body becomes even thinner, eats little, is warm to the touch, and is easily startled and irritable. His urine is delayed and turns white, and there are two-inch polyps in his nose. There is a small lump in the neck, hidden between the muscles. I believe this is a transformation due to deficiency in the liver and spleen. Not trusting this, they cleared internal lung fire and applied corrosives externally, resulting in throat corrosion. I initially used a modified Wumei Yigong Powder with Shengma, Chaihu, and Wutui as the main ingredients, supplemented with the Four-Flavor Fei'Er Pill, which gradually strengthened the spleen's energy; in the evening, I used the Nine-Flavor Aloe Pill as the main treatment, supplemented with Wumei Yigong Powder, and he recovered.

    Another child has difficulty urinating, a dry nose, and nosebleeds, with a red color in his nostrils; he has heat in the spleen and lungs. I used the Jisheng Xijiao Dihuang Decoction, and the previous condition was resolved. Later, the area below the chin remains red, thirst occurs, and there is phlegm, indicating insufficient kidney qi. I used the Dihuang Pill, and all conditions were healed.

    Xue’s "External Medicine Heart Method" states that a child has sores on the outside of the nose, which, if not rubbed regularly, extend to both ears, and various drugs are ineffective. Using the Aloe Pill for oral intake and applying rosin and mung bean powder led to recovery.

    A child has a cough with wheezing, high fever, chills, skin resembling millet, an itchy nose with a runny nose, a sore throat, rotten gums with blood, abdominal distension with a feeling of fullness, and diarrhea, named lung syphilis. I treated it with the Dihuang Qingfei Drink and the Xia (Shangniuxia) Pills for a cure.[166p]
