If there is no residual poison, it leads to risks of weakness, which should not be overlooked.[38p]

    　　　　　雀目

    　　小儿雀目，属肝脾二经。脾弱者健脾，肝虚者养血，宜分两途。饮食面色如常，但夜不能见物，还明饮妙。
    　　　　小儿卫生总微论方 【宋　撰人未详】
    　　　　　解颅

    　　肾气盛者，顖小而合早；肾气怯者，解颅而顖不合。颅不瘥而病交攻，极难将护，最为大病。
    　　　　　顖门肿陷论

    　　小儿初生，皆有顖门者，脏气未充，骨髓未完，滋养未备故也。脏腑皆以脾胃为养，儿自生以后，得五谷所滋，则脏气充而骨髓完，所以儿至能食则顖门合也。顖门者，系于脾胃。《圣济经》言卫顖之天五，五者土也，脾胃属焉。小儿有顖肿者，由脾胃不和，冷热不调，或怒啼饮乳，或喘急咳嗽，致阴阳气逆上冲而顖肿也。热则肿而软，冷则肿而硬。又有顖陷者，或因泻痢，或小便频数，或曾服清药以利小便，或本怯气弱，或别病缠绵，皆使脏虚而不能上荣于顖，故令顖陷也。此皆小儿恶证，得愈者鲜矣。[39p]

    Sparrow's Fontanelle

    For young children, the condition of the fontanelle relates to the liver and spleen channels. If the spleen is weak, strengthen the spleen; if the liver is deficient, nourish the blood. These should be treated in two ways. The child’s diet and complexion may appear normal, but they cannot see at night, thus it is advisable to use restorative drinks.

    Cranial Relief

    In children, strong kidney energy results in the fontanelle being small and closed early; whereas weak kidney energy leads to an open fontanelle. If the fontanelle does not heal, the illness may attack repeatedly, making it extremely difficult to protect the child, which is a serious condition.

    Discussion on Swollen and Sunken Fontanelle

    All newborns have a fontanelle, as their internal energy is not yet full, their bone marrow is not complete, and nourishment is insufficient. Internal organs rely on the spleen and stomach for nourishment. After birth, when the child is fed with grains, their internal energy is replenished and bone marrow matures, leading to the closing of the fontanelle once they can eat. The fontanelle is connected to the spleen and stomach. The "Seng Ji Jing" states that the fontanelle is connected to earth, which corresponds to the spleen and stomach. If a child has a swollen fontanelle, it is due to disharmony in the spleen and stomach, imbalance of hot and cold, angry crying when fed, or wheezing and coughing, leading to a reversal of Yin and Yang energy that causes the fontanelle to swell. It swells and feels soft with heat, and swells and feels hard with cold. A sunken fontanelle may result from diarrhea, frequent urination, past intake of cleansing medicines, inherent weak energy, or lingering other illnesses, all of which render the internal organs deficient and unable to nourish the fontanelle, hence causing it to sink. These are all severe conditions for children, and few manage to recover.[39p]

    　　　　　头上诸病论

    　　小儿头上生软疖者，由风邪冷热之气客于皮肤，持于血气，壅滞经络，蕴结而生，亦如身上生疖无异，但生在头上。始则赤肿而硬，其邪微者，散则自消；其邪甚者，肿赤内搐，溃脓血作痛。以头上皮紧，至熟多不能去脓根，中有恶汁不尽，因而复发，或在根边别生，连续不瘥，常常拱脓，故名曰软疖。　　小儿头有秃疮者，按九虫论云：是蛲虫动作，与风邪相乘，上于头之皮肤，搏于血气，伤其荣卫而所生也。荣为血，受病则为赤秃；卫为气，受病则为白秃。荣在内，邪稍难干，故患赤秃者少；卫在外，邪易得着，故患白秃者多。[40p]

    On Various Head Diseases

    Soft boils that appear on a child's head are caused by the invasion of wind and cold, affecting the skin, lingering in the blood and qi, obstructing the meridians, and accumulating to form these boils, similar to those that arise on the body but located on the head. Initially, they appear red and swollen and hard; if the pathogen is mild, it may dissipate on its own. However, if the pathogen is severe, the swelling becomes red and painful, producing pus and blood. Due to the tightness of the scalp, it is often difficult to fully remove the pus when it becomes mature; there may be residual foul fluid that leads to recurrence or the emergence of new boils at the edges, resulting in continuous non-healing, often painfully abscessing, hence the name soft boils.

    For children with bald patches on the head, according to the Nine Worms theory: this is caused by pinworms interacting with wind pathogens, affecting the skin of the head, colliding with the blood and qi, and injuring the nourishing and protective aspects. The nourishing aspect relates to blood; when diseased, it leads to red baldness; the protective aspect relates to qi; when diseased, it causes white baldness. As the nourishing aspect is internal, it is more difficult for pathogens to affect it, hence cases of red baldness are rare; meanwhile, as the protective aspect is external, pathogens can easily invade, leading to more cases of white baldness.[40p]

    其始生如癣之斑点，上有皮屑，渐渐作痂，以成其疮，遂至满头发落殆尽。若刮去其痂，则疮皆是孔眼，大小不等。如虫之窠，有脓汁出，不痛而痒，痒乃不可禁，是知有虫为风也。又一种俗呼为鬼舐头，小儿有头疮，过夜被鬼舐之，则引及满头有赤痂，或云便赤秃也。　　小儿头疮者，由脏腑有热，上冲于头，外被风湿，复相乘之，搏于血气而生其疮，故曰头疮。此候与秃疮特异。且秃疮者，有白有赤，硬痂遍满其头。此头疮者，但一两处生其痂，并不白硬而干，时时常有脓血湿汁，俗呼为长头疮，小儿失于沐发者，便生此疮也。[41p]

    At first, it appears like spots of scabs, with flakes of skin on top. Gradually, it forms crusts, leading to wounds that ultimately result in nearly complete hair loss. If the crusts are scraped off, the wounds are filled with holes of varying sizes. There is pus that oozes out, and while there is no pain, there is an unbearable itch, indicating the presence of a "wind" insect. There is also a condition commonly called "ghost licking the head," where a child with a scalp sore is said to be licked by a ghost overnight, resulting in red crusts covering the head, sometimes referred to as "red baldness."

    The cause of a child's scalp sore is internal heat affecting the organs, which then rises to the head. Coupled with external wind and moisture, these factors combine, impacting the blood and qi, thereby leading to the sores, hence it is called scalp sores. This condition is distinct from bald sores. Bald sores can appear both white and red, with hard crusts covering the entire head. In contrast, scalp sores might only appear in one or two spots, lacking the whitish, hard, dry texture, often exuding pus and blood. Commonly referred to as "long scalp sores," these are known to occur when children fail to wash their hair properly.[41p]

    　　　　　发

    　　心气盛者，形神清而多发；心气怯者，发久不生，生则不黑。心主血，发为血之余，怯则久不生也。
    　　　　　耳中诸病论

    　　小儿有忽患耳聋沉听者，由风邪乘于手太阳之经也。邪随其经，入于耳内，邪正相搏，气停塞滞，则令耳聋不能聪听于音声也。轻者则为沉听，谓耳中沉沉然，轻小之音则不辨，重大之声才闻也。[42p]

    About Hair

    Those with a vigorous heart and spirit have clear forms and abundant hair; those with a timid heart have little to no hair growth, and if it does grow, it lacks color. The heart governs the blood, and hair is considered the surplus of blood; thus, timidity leads to prolonged absence of growth.

    Discussion on Diseases of the Ear

    When a child suddenly suffers from deafness or diminished hearing, it is due to the invasion of wind pathogens affecting the Hand Taiyang channel. The pathogen follows this channel and enters the ear; when the pathogen clashes with the correct energy, it causes stagnation and blockage, resulting in deafness and inability to hear sounds. In mild cases, it may result in diminished hearing, where the ear feels heavy, making it hard to distinguish faint sounds, while louder noises can still be heard.[42p]

    　　　　　耳中鸣痛

    　　小儿有耳中或鸣或痛者，由风邪入耳，与正气相干，搏于血气者即为鸣，搏于经络者即为痛也。
    　　　　　耳中肿疮出脓汁

    　　小儿有耳中肿或生疮出脓汁者，由风湿相乘入于耳，邪正相干，搏于气血，伤于经络，轻则为肿，重则生疮。若津液结溃，变为脓血汁出。又有因水或眼泪入耳，停搏正气，亦为脓汁，俱名聤耳，又名脓耳也。
    　　　　　眼目病论

    　　小儿眼目生病者，多因恣食甘酸，脏生邪热，熏炙肝经，冲发于目，或为赤肿痒痛，或眵泪隐濇，或生赤脉，或生翳膜。又痰饮毒气渍肝，致脏气不得宣通者，则精华未得明审；故黑睛虽全而视物(目巟)(目巟)，此名睛盲。若昼日明，至瞑不见物者，此邪干经之阴也，谓之雀目。言如鸟雀之目，瞑时无所见也。又有障眼者，乃气毒障幔其睛也。又有肝疳之气冲于目者，亦能生其翳膜以为遮障也。[43p]

    Ear Noises and Pain

    If a child experiences ringing or pain in the ears, it is due to the invasion of wind evil into the ears, which interferes with vital energy. If it collides with blood and qi, it results in ringing; if it affects the meridians, it leads to pain.

    Ear Swelling and Pus

    If a child has swelling or sores in the ears producing pus, it results from a combination of wind and dampness entering the ears, affecting the opposition between evil and vital energy, colliding with qi and blood, and damaging the meridians. If mild, it causes swelling; if severe, sores may develop. If bodily fluids accumulate and break down, pus and blood may emerge. Additionally, if water or tears enter the ears, obstructing vital energy, this too can lead to pus, commonly referred to as "tinnitus" or "purulent ear."

    Eye Diseases Discussion

    When a child has eye diseases, it is often due to excessive consumption of sweet and sour foods, generating internal heat and affecting the liver meridian, which manifests in the eyes. This may lead to redness, swelling, itching, or pain; excessive tearing; the presence of red veins; or the formation of membranes. If phlegm, dampness, and toxic qi invade the liver, causing its energy to become obstructed, then clarity is not achieved; hence, even if the pupils are intact, vision may be impaired, a condition termed "dimming vision." If one cannot see during the day, it is considered an evil affecting the yin of the meridians, known as "night blindness," akin to a bird that cannot see in the dark. Additionally, there can be eye obstructions caused by toxic qi covering the eyes, or liver heat impacting the eyes, which can also lead to membrane formation as a barrier.[43p]

    　　　　　鼻中病论

    　　肺气通于鼻，气不和为风冷所乘，停滞鼻中，搏于津液，使涕凝结壅，气不通快，不闻臭香，谓之鼻塞。若风冷搏于血气，而生息肉塞滞者，谓之齆鼻。若风湿相搏，则鼻内生疮而有脓汁出也，若脑热攻鼻中干燥，或生疮痂，则硬而无脓汁也。
    　　　　幼幼近编 【明　陈治】

    　　　　　解颅

    　　解颅者，肾气有亏，脑髓不足，湿热上熏，故头缝解开不合也。宜地黄丸加鹿茸、酒炒片芩。亦有气虚有热者，宜四君子加酒芩。　　《衍义》治解颅，以蟹螯同白芨捣烂，敷顖上。
    　　　　　顖陷

    　　顖陷者，气血脾胃俱虚而元气下陷也，宜补中益气汤；手足冷者，加姜、桂，甚至加附子。
    　　　　　顖填

    　　顖填者，脾胃元气虚而气逆上冲也，亦有脾胃虚热者，有脾胃湿热者，并宜异功散加酒芩、木香、蔓荆子；湿热上熏者加苍朮。[44p]

    Discussion on Nasal Disorders

    The lung qi communicates with the nose. If the qi is not harmonized, it can be invaded by wind and cold, becoming stagnant in the nose, obstructing the fluids and causing mucus to congeal, resulting in blocked nasal passages, which is termed nasal obstruction. If wind and cold obstruct the blood qi, causing the formation of flesh-like obstructions, it is called nasal polyp. If wind and dampness interact, sores and purulent discharge may develop in the nose. If heat from the brain attacks the nose leading to dryness, or if sores and scabs form, they may be hard and devoid of purulent discharge.
    — From the "Young and Young Near Compilation" by Chen Zhi (Ming Dynasty)

    Nasal Collapse

    Nasal collapse occurs due to deficiency of kidney qi, leading to insufficient brain marrow, with damp heat ascending, causing the cranial sutures to separate and not align. It is advisable to use Di Huang Wan with deer antler and fried Baizhu. For those with qi deficiency and heat, the Four Gentlemen Decoction with fried Baizhu is recommended. The "Expanded Meaning" suggests treating nasal collapse with crab claws mixed with Rhizoma Bletillae, ground into a paste and applied to the crown.

    Nasal Depression

    Nasal depression occurs when qi and blood are both deficient and the original qi sinks. It is suitable to use the Middle-Qi Boosting Decoction; if the hands and feet are cold, add ginger, cassia, and even prepared aconite.

    Nasal Filling

    Nasal filling occurs due to deficiency of the spleen and stomach leading to a reversal of qi that ascends. There may also be spleen-stomach heat or damp heat present. In these cases, it is advisable to use Yigong San with fried Baizhu, Mu Xiang, and Viticis Fructus. If damp heat ascends, add Atractylodes.[44p]

    　　　　东医宝鉴 【朝鲜　徐浚】

    　　　　　项软

    　　项软者，天柱骨倒也，宜用健骨散、生筋散。　　小儿久患疳疾，体虚不食，及诸病后天柱骨倒，医者不识，谓之五软。　　小儿因风颈项软头不得正，或去前，或去后，宜用天柱丸、五加皮散；风热项软，合用凉肝丸方。
    　　　　　发不生

    　　　　　胎患

    　　初生观物转睛不快，至四五岁瞳人洁白，昏蒙不见，延至年高无药治，由胎中受热致损也。
    　　　　　通睛

    　　婴儿双眼睛通者，欲观东边则见西边。苦振掉头脑，则睛方转，此肝受惊风，宜服牛黄丸。
    　　　　　眼中生赘

    　　眼睑中生赘子，初生如麻子大，日渐如豆，悬垂睑内，此脾经风热所攻，宜服五退散加减。
    　　　　　青盲

    　　胎中受风，五脏不和，呕吐黄汁，两眼一同，视物不明，无治法。青盲者，瞳子黑白分明，直视物而不见者也。[45p]

    Dongyi Baojian [Joseon, Xu Jun]

    Nape Weakness

    Nape weakness refers to the Tianzhu bone being misplaced; it is advisable to use Jian Gu San and Sheng Jin San. When a child suffers from long-term malnutrition and has a weak body, or when the Tianzhu bone is displaced due to various illnesses, and the physician cannot identify it, this is known as five weaknesses. If a child has a soft neck due to wind, causing the head to tilt forward or backward, Tianzhu Wan and Wujia Pi San should be used; if due to wind-heat, it is appropriate to use Liang Gan Wan.

    Hair Not Growing

    Hair not growing is due to insufficient nourishment of qi and blood, failing to nourish the hair; it is advisable to take Congrong Wan.

    Fetal Disorders

    If a newborn shows a lack of quick eye movement when observing objects, and by age four or five the pupils are completely white and unclear, extending into old age without treatment, this is due to excessive heat received during gestation.

    Eyes Not Aligning

    If an infant’s eyes are misaligned, wanting to look east but seeing west, and shaking their head continually affects sight, this is due to the liver being disturbed by wind; it is advisable to take Niu Huang Wan.

    Eye Growths

    If growths appear on the eyelids, starting as large as a sesame seed and gradually growing like a bean, hanging down inside the eyelid, this is caused by wind-heat attacking the spleen channel; it is advisable to take Wutui San with modifications.

    Color Blindness

    If a fetus is affected by wind, leading to disharmony of the internal organs, resulting in vomiting yellow bile, both eyes being unclear in vision without any treatment method, this condition of color blindness refers to pupils being distinctly black and white but unable to see objects clearly.[45p]

    Kang Eye

    Children with kang-eye or strabismus may be blind or have retinas that do not see; they may also have pus. It is advisable to prepare liver pills and Longdan decoction.

    Prescriptions for Children’s Head and Facial Conditions

    Kushen Decoction (from "Qianjin Fang")
    To treat head sores in children:
    1 liang of Kushen, Huangqin, Huanglian, Huangkua, Gancao, Dahuang, and Xiongshang;
    3 he of Zhilizi.
    Combine these eight ingredients (after chopping), use 6 sheng of water, boil down to 3 sheng, and soak cloth to apply to sores, several times a day.

    Lilu Paste
    To treat all head sores in children, especially those that have persisted and become carbuncles, itch without scabbing:
    2 liang of Lilu, Huanglian, Xionghuang, Huangqin, and pine resin;
    ½ jin of pig fat;
    5 liang of alum stone.
    Grind these seven ingredients into a powder, boil until combined, wash with a decoction of Red Dragon Skin and Tianma before applying. Red Dragon Skin refers to Quercus wood bark.

    Six-Flavor Rehmannia Pill (from "Qian's Direct Formula")
    To treat children with physical weakness, relieve concave temples, sparse and short hair that appears scorched yellow, may also suffer from hearing loss or tinnitus, with liver deficiency and internal heat, pale blue eye color:
    8 qian of cooked Rehmannia, wine-washed Chuanzao,
    4 qian each of Shanyao and Shanxiong;
    3 qian each of Zexie, Mudanpi, and Baizhu.
    Grind these into a powder, mix with Rehmannia paste, add enough rice paste to form pills the size of a tung seed. Take several pills with warm water on an empty stomach.[46p]

    "Divide the above into fine powder, apply cow's milk to the forehead, and it will resolve in ten days.
    Dai Lian Qiao Decoction treats sores and rashes with strong heat, difficulty in urination, various types of sores and abscesses, and the dan poison of the navel wind.     Chai Hu Powder treats children with wind-heat without sweating, showing exterior symptoms of strong heat, headache, body pain, dry mouth and thirst, red urine, and constipation with abdominal distention. Ingredients: Shi Gao (Gypsum), Huang Qin, Gan Cao, Chi Shao Yao, and Ge Gen, each 2.5 pennies; Ma Huang (Ephedra) without stems, and Chai Hu half a tael. Grind and powder, for a three-year-old child, take 2 pennies with one cup of water, a slice of fresh ginger, and three inches of scallion, decoct until half a cup remains, and take at any time.

    Feng Yan San Zhang Huan Formula: Take 1 tael of snake skin, burn to ash and finely grind; use 5 fen of wet Da Huang wrapped in paper and cooked to preserve its properties; Bai Ji and Fang Feng, each half a tael. Change with each application."[48p]

    Tiao Yuan San (Regulating the Original Vital Energy Powder)

    The main symptoms include insufficient reception of original qi, an open cranial fontanelle, emaciated muscles, an abdomen swollen like a tumor, delayed speech and movement, hands and feet resembling tubes, a dull and lethargic expression, delayed tooth eruption, and a notable effect from taking this remedy.

    Ingredients:

    • Aged yam (with black skin removed) - 5 qian
    • Ginseng (skin removed)
    • White poria (skin removed)
    • Poria spirit (skin removed)
    • Atractylodes macrocephala
    • White peony root
    • Prepared rehmannia (washed with wine)
    • Dong quai (washed with wine)
    • Astragalus (honey water roasted) - each 2.5 qian
    • Sichuan lovage
    • Licorice (roasted) - each 3 qian
    • Stone calamus - 2 qian

    Crush these ingredients; each dose is 2 qian, mixed with one cup of water, two slices of ginger, and one date, boiled until reduced to seven parts. This should be taken warm at any time. For infants with cough, they may take it with the nursing mother.

    Yu Ru Dan (Jade Milk Pill by Zhang Huan)

    This is for infants whose cranial bones do not align properly, and the sutures are open.

    Ingredients:

    • Bellflower powder made according to ancient methods
    • Aged dried rehmannia steamed and baked
    • Biota seeds ground separately
    • Dong quai (washed and baked) - each half liang
    • Siler - 1 fen
    • Psoralea (carefully selected and lightly roasted) - 1 fen

    Grind the items (except those ground separately) into a fine powder, then mix with the bellflower powder and stir well. Shape them with honey to the size of millet grains. Each dose consists of ten grains, taken with boiled fennel soup before meals. Optionally, add astragalus and poria.[49p]

    Dog Brain Pill: For treating children's head growth, which causes them to shake their heads and relieve pressure in the skull. One dog brain, five parts of Chaiqi (an herb), licorice roasted, white atractylodes, fangfeng (siler), shanzhuyu (mulu horse), and dried rehmannia, each one part; two parts of ox gall. Make into pills the size of small beans. For a one-year-old, give two pills twice a day, and increase as appropriate. It is also said: Keep the child's head warm; if cold, they may die.

    Tiger Bone Formula: For treating children's head relief.
    Use half a liang of tiger bone, half a liang of broken turtle shell, half a liang of non-ash wood, and half a liang of frankincense. Make into powder, and use fresh pig’s blood in the palm of your hand to mix and apply to the opening of the skull sutures, wrapping with old cotton paper for seven days. On the eighth day, wash off the previous medicine with scallion broth and reapply this medicine. For those who have undergone this for a year, reduce by one part, rest for three days, and then continue applying the medicine; also take Shenling powder.

    Shenling Powder:
    Ingredients include one part of ginseng, one part of poria, roasted white atractylodes, qianghuo, roasted licorice, peony, and white atractylodes, each one part; reduce rhino horn shavings, JXiao (a type of angelica), and peppermint to half. Make into powder, and for each dose, take half a qian, boiled in a cup of water with a little silver and three leaves of mint until reduced by a third; take warm, to soothe the spirit.[50p]

    Zhuang's family prescriptions for treating unaligned cranial sutures:

    • Mountain herb, one or two parts
    • Plantain seed, half a tael
    • Lily bulb, half a tael

    Grind these into a powder, mix with buffalo milk, and apply to the feet and cranial sutures. Wrap the head with cloth, change every three days, and it will surely take effect after five applications.

    Wang's powder for treating opened cranial sutures, with symptoms of a widened suture, depression at the top of the head, coughing, and nasal congestion:

    • Arborvitae seeds, four taels
    • Siler, four taels
    • South star, four taels

    Grind into fine powder. For each use, take one penny and mix with pig gall juice to the right consistency, apply on a piece of red silk fabric cut to the size of the cranial fontanel, change daily, keep it moist with broth.

    Angelica powder for treating heat in the child's organs, causing thirst and resulting in diarrhea and dysentery. If prolonged, it weakens the blood energy, failing to nourish the brain, leading to depression of the fontanel:

    • Angelica, two parts
    • White peony root, two parts
    • Ginseng, two parts
    • Honey-fried licorice, two parts
    • Balloon flower, one penny
    • Dried tangerine peel, one penny

    Grind into powder, decoct in half a cup of water, and administer in small doses as needed.

    Black affusion paste for treating depression of the fontanel:

    • Use five pennies of both black mountain herb and black aconite
    • Two pennies of realgar

    Grind these into powder, finely chop and pound fresh scallions along with their roots and leaves, add to the powdered mixture and decoct, forming a paste to apply to the depressed area.[51p]

    Thirty-six Remedies for Plastering the Neck

    For the first remedy: equal parts of Aconitum (Caowu) and red beans (Chixiaodou). Grind to a powder, mix with ginger juice, apply to cloth, and plaster on the neck to promptly alleviate symptoms.

    For the second remedy: Ji's neck plaster for children. It treats heat in the liver and coolness in the gallbladder, where the head and neck are soft and drooping. Ingredients include one qian each of Chuanwu, cinnamon (Rougui), mustard seeds (Yuntaizi), southern star (Nansxing), and castor seeds (Bimozi), along with one qian of fried yellow ochre. Grind the ingredients finely. Use one whole garlic, cook until soft, peel, and grind in a mortar, mixing thoroughly with the medicine. Use one qian of the mixture, blend it with rice vinegar, and apply to the neck for about a day.

    For the third remedy: Ji's wolf poison pills. This treats heat in the gallbladder and liver wind in children, especially when presenting with an upside-down neck. It is recommended to take this medicine along with the plaster mentioned above. For the ingredients: wolf poison soaked and roasted, white and large Aconitum (Bai Fuzi and Da Fuzi), Tianma, Fangfeng, Qianghuo, each one fen; one qian each of cinnabar and earthworm (Dilong) cleaned of soil; half a word of musk. Grind to a fine powder, mix into pills with medicinal liquor that is thick, about the size of a small bean. Take seven to fifteen pills with black bean and mint soup, with a drop of liquor to swallow down.

    For the fourth remedy: Jade Dew Drink. This treats the swelling and redness in the throat of children, as well as cheek redness, dry throat, body heat, and headaches. Use one liang each of cold water stone (Han shuishi) with fine veins that can be crushed, and gypsum (Shigao), which is pure white, hard, and has walls. Add three qian of dried licorice (Gancao) dried in the shade or baked by fire. Grind all ingredients except the first two into a fine powder. Use half a qian to one qian, mixed with warm water as needed, or with wheat winter soup (Maidong Tang).[53p]

    Fangfeng Decoction: Treats the same conditions.
    Fangfeng, Qianghuo, and Zhishi each 250 grams; Chuanxiong, roasted Gan-Cao, and stewed Dahuang each 25 grams. Grind them into a fine powder. Take three pinches each time, boiled with ginger and jujube.

    Jinye Pill: For children with cold stomach, spleen obstruction, extreme vomiting and diarrhea, leading to a sunken fontanelle. Use ten taels of sulfur, finely ground and placed in a magnetic container. Seal with eight parts water and red stone resin, reinforced with salty mud, and sun-dry. Bury a small jar full of water, place the container on top, seal again with salty mud, and calcine with charcoal for three days and nights. After cooling, take out and grind into a fine powder. Each time take two taels, consumed with ginger soup.

    Guzhen Decoction: Treats the same conditions.
    Ren Shen (ginseng) without its husk, Fu Zi (prepared Aconite) soaked and split, without skin; Bai Fu Ling (white Poria) without skin; Bai Zhu (white Atractylodes) each 25 grams; Shan Yao (Chinese yam) without black skin; Huang Qi (Astragalus) honey-water roasted; Rou Gui (cinnamon) without rough bark; Gan Cao (licorice) wrapped in damp paper, stewed through, each 25 grams. Grind the ingredients and take two taels each time, boiled in one cup of water with three slices of ginger and one jujube, cooked down to seven parts, taken warm on an empty stomach or at any time.[54p]

    Head Lice Recipe
    One ounce of rosin, melted with dry pan and placed on a stone, cooled and taken up, then ground finely. Black dragon tail is used to hang down to catch dust. Three qian each of yellow lead and ochre, half an ounce of white atractylodes, and two qian each of mercury, realgar, and white alum. Mix these into a powder, then simmer with leftover blood and fragrant oil until dissolved, and apply to the affected area.

    Head Sore Recipe
    One qian of lard, half raw and half cooked, two and a half qian each of realgar and mercury. Grind and mix well, and apply to the sore.

    Scab Head Recipe
    Half an ounce each of ligusticum, scutellaria (washed with wine), peony (washed with wine), and dried tangerine peel; one ounce each of white atractylodes and angelica (washed with wine); seven and a half qian of gastrodia (washed with wine); seven and a half qian of xanthium; three qian each of coptis, powdered grass, and saposhnikovia. Chew these ingredients and decoct, taking the medicine four to five times, and rest afterwards.

    Holy Ointment
    For treating soft abscesses on children's heads. One ounce of vegetable oil, half an ounce of yellow wax, one qian of pitch, half a qian of ochre, and one marrow from a sheep's bone. Cook these into an ointment, spread on paper and apply to the affected area. Place a piece of cold iron on the sore to hold it down, then prick around the edges if pus does not drain out quickly, using paper wicks to absorb it. Do not let the medicine touch copper or iron utensils.[56p]

    The following is the translated text:

    Right is the powder, take one qian each time, mixed with licorice decoction.

    Fatted Child Pill cures weakness of the spleen and stomach in children, decreased appetite. The spleen governs the muscles; if the flesh is thin-skinned and the fontanel is visible, it is not retracted. Ingredients include: ginseng, white atractylodes, white poria, yam (steamed), white lotus seed, and angelica, five qian each; dried tangerine peel, two qian; green peel, mu xiang, sand ginger, quinyu, shenqu, three qian each; roasted licorice, balloon flower, malt, two qian each. Right is ground into powder, soaked in lotus leaf water and boiled, then made into pills the size of sesame seeds. Take fifteen, twenty-five, thirty-five, forty-five, up to fifty pills, with rice drink.

    Ginseng and Atractylodes Powder treats weakness of the spleen and stomach in children, with visible fontanel. Ingredients include: half a dong of white hyacinth bean, soaked in ginger juice to remove the skin and lightly fried; ginseng, white poria, white atractylodes, roasted licorice, yam, each three dong; lotus meat, fried balloon flower, coix seeds, sand ginger, each two dong. Right is ground into powder, take one qian each time, mixed with date soup.

    Ten Complete Great Tonic Decoction treats kidney deficiency and insufficient vital energy in children. Ingredients include: white poria, ginseng, angelica, white atractylodes, fried astragalus, chuangxiong, fried white peony, cinnamon, cooked rehmannia, roasted licorice, all in equal parts. Take three to five qian, decocted in ginger date water.[58p]

    Tong Sheng San (from "Zheng Zhi Zhun Sheng")
    To treat children's marrow heat and relieve the scalp, for smallpox invading the eyes and causing membranes to form. Use white chrysanthemum; if unavailable, substitute with sweet chrysanthemum, but white chrysanthemum is preferred. Also, use soybean pod skins and the roots of valley herb, each one tael. Grind finely. Each dose is one large coin, with one dried persimmon and one bowl of rice wash, decoct together until the rice wash is reduced. Remove the pit from the persimmon and consume it; there are no restrictions regarding the time, take three pieces daily. Improvement is noted within five to seven days for those nearby, and within half a month for those further away.

    Feng Yan Fa (from Wan's prescriptions)
    Equal parts of: Fang Feng, Nan Xing, Bai Lian, Bai Ji. Grind to a powder, mix with crushed pig brain and seal on the scalp, changing it three times a day.

    Yi Huang San (from "Wei Sheng Zong Wei")
    To treat children's scalp swelling, hardness, and sinking, with spleen channel deficiency heat and slightly yellowish color in the eyes. Use one tael of dried tangerine peel, five qian each of green tangerine peel, haritaki fruit, and roasted licorice; two qian of clove. Grind finely. Each dose is two qian with one bowl of water, decoct until reduced to two-thirds, taken warm before meals. In Wan's supplements, replace it with Yi Gong San.

    Yuan Jing Shi San
    To treat children's scalp sores. One fen each of Taiyin Yuanjing Stone and Han Shui Stone, grind into a fine powder, plus a little light powder and musk. First, wash the sore with diluted paste, dry it, and apply the medicinal mixture; for severe cases, repeat no more than twice.[59p]

    Gua Lou San (Trichosanthes Powder): For treatment, the symptoms are the same as above.
    One piece of gua lou, mix with one handful of salt and fermented beans inside, combine and burn to ash, then grind into powder. One part of yellow earth from below the stove, and one part of greasy powder. Mix these together, add a little musk, and stir well. Use a small amount, mix with oil, and apply to moist areas to dry.

    Dan Chi San (Light Fermented Bean Powder): For treatment, the symptoms are the same as above.
    Fry blackened light fermented beans until dry, each one tael of red alum, and two qian of greasy powder. Crush the first two ingredients into powder, mix with the powder and grind well. First, use mulberry wood ash diluted with juice to wash the wound clean, apply powdered licorice to the wound, then apply raw oil mixed with the medicine. For moist areas, use to dry.

    Huang Lian San (Coptis Powder): For treatment, the symptoms are the same as above.
    Two taels of Coptis without roots and one tael of Hu Powder. Grind finely, first wash away the scabs from the wound, pat dry, and apply. It will heal. If it reappears, use again.

    Hu Fen Gao (Hu Powder Ointment): For the treatment of longstanding scalp wounds that have not healed for years.
    One and a half taels each of pine resin, bitter root, and Coptis (roots removed), one tael each of fresh rhubarb, Hu powder, and honeysuckle, half a tael of white alum, and three fen of snake bed seeds. Grind these into a fine powder, mix with pig fat from December, until no mercury specks are visible, and apply. Another formula for treating longstanding scalp wounds.
    Burn walnut and skin until charred, use a bowl to catch the fire's toxins, grind into powder, and mix with a little greasy powder. Apply this fine powder with raw oil, and shave the hair over the wound before application, just once or twice.[60p]

    Lai Tou Fang
    Pine tree bark is burned to ash. Boil white resin and pour it over stones; two taels. Grind yellow lead to a fine powder; one tael. One tael each of soft gypsum, yellow gentian, rhubarb, and white alum, all processed with heat; five qian each. Four portions of light powder.     Sheng Hui Shen Xiao Sheng Fa Hei Dou Gao
    Used to treat children's scalp issues, where hair grows into tufts and falls out completely; also effective for white patches on the scalp. For those lacking hair, it encourages hair growth.
    Three heaping cups of black beans and jute; one tael of harad peel.
    Grind these ingredients to a powder, mix with water until smooth, and place in a bamboo tube, sealing the top with tangled hair. Use furnace ash to extract oil, storing it in a ceramic container. First, wash the head with rice water and soap pod soup, dry it, and then apply. Use twice daily for ten days to stimulate growth.

    Another Formula
    Two taels each of kudzu root powder, pig lard, and sheep lard.
    Mix these ingredients in a small pot and simmer over low heat to create a paste, storing it in a ceramic container. Take one qian of the paste to apply to the scalp daily, no more than five to seven applications for effectiveness.

    Treatment for Facial Sores with Yellow Discharge
    One portion of fermented soybeans, roasted until black;
    One tael of Coptis, finely ground.
    First, wash the sore with hot ash-water to clean it, then dry and apply. This also treats similar sores on the body.

    Treatment for Red, Swollen, Painful Facial Sores
    Eight taels of ground Yao (the root of a plant);
    Add one dou (about 10 liters) of water, boil down to five sheng (about 1.5 liters), and filter out the dregs; use for washing both hot and cold.

    Five Happiness Detox Pills
    To treat fetal toxicity and sores appearing on the head and face after smallpox, accompanied by swelling and pain:
    Three taels each of fresh Rehmannia Paste, cooked Rehmannia Paste, Asparagus root (with core removed), and Ophiopogon root (with core removed);
    Two taels each of fresh licorice and sweet saltpetre;
    One tael and five qian of indigo powder.
    Grind all into a powder, mix with honey to form pills the size of water chestnuts. Take one pill dissolved in hot water. Sweet saltpetre refers to nitre that has been processed in boiling water. Xue Ji states: If taking this leads to convulsions, phlegm, or wheezing, it indicates injury to the middle qi resulting in false heat; urgently take the Five Flavored Different Efficacies Powder. If both hands and feet are cold, this indicates deficiency and cold in the middle qi; add ginger and cinnamon to the previous decoction.

    　　芦荟丸 【《庄氏家传》】 　治小儿自脱胎时两目赤肿，或作痒生翳，及肾肝疳热，致耳聋聩或虚鸣。　　芦荟一钱，别研秤，或只以皂角水磨　草龙胆一两，洗净銼焙干秤　　右件药一处捣罗为末，用不蚛皂角三梃，以水二升挼汁，用生绢滤去滓，入银器内，慢火熬成膏，入前二味调和得所，丸如菉豆大，每服三丸至五丸，薄荷汤下。[66p]

    Gardenia Liver Clearing Powder (also known as Bupleurum Gardenia Powder): Treats dryness of the liver meridian blood, which leads to deafness and tinnitus, yellowish eyes, eyelid spasms, and belongs to the conditions resulting from wind-heat conflict.

    Ingredients:

    • Bupleurum,
    • Fried Gardenia,
    • Peony root (each 3 grams),
    • Poria,
    • Chuanxiong,
    • White Peony root,
    • Angelica sinensis,
    • Fried Burdock seed (each 4.5 grams),
    • Licorice (1.5 grams).

    Preparation: Boil with water and take as a decoction.

    Nine-Flavor Aloe Vera Pill: Treats the same condition.
    Ingredients:

    • Hu Huang Lian,
    • Coptis chinensis,
    • White Vile,
    • Aloe Vera,
    • Saussurea costus,
    • Green Peel,
    • Bai Lei Wan (open the red ones do not use),
    • Fried Herba Hedyotis (each 15 grams),
    • Musk (6 grams, ground separately).

    Preparation: Make into powder, form into pills the size of mung beans, take 20 pills each time, wash down with rice drink.

    Aloe Vera Pill from Zhuang Family Tradition: Treats children with red and swollen eyes from birth, or those with itching and opacity, and kidney-liver heat causing deafness or tinnitus.

    Ingredients:

    • Aloe Vera (3 grams, ground),
    • Dragon Grass (30 grams, washed, grated, and dried).

    Preparation: Combine the above herbs, grind them into powder, mix with 1.5 liters of water crushed juice from non-maggot soapberry, filter with raw silk, and slowly boil in a silver container to make a paste. Then incorporate the first two ingredients until well mixed, and form pills the size of mung beans. Take 3 to 5 pills each time, wash down with mint tea.[66p]

    　　清上散 【《证治准绳》，下同】 　治上焦风热，耳出脓汁，头面疮疖；亦治胎热眼睛肿赤，粪色稠黄，肚胀啼哭及身上红肿。　　川郁金　甘草　北桔梗　天花粉　干葛　薄荷叶各等分　　右为末，入蜜拌匀，白汤下三五七分或一钱。仍用艾叶煎浓汤，温浸足底，以引其热下行。
    　　当归芦荟丸　治肝胆风热，耳中鸣，出青脓，名曰震耳，大便秘，小便黄。常服宣通血气，调顺阴阳。　　当归　龙胆草　柴胡各一两　青黛　胆星　大黄　芦荟各五钱　麝香五分　栀子仁　黄芩　黄连　黄蘗各一两　木香二钱五分　　右为末，炼蜜丸小豆大，每服二十丸，姜汤送下。[67p]

    Qing Shang San
    To treat wind-heat in the upper jiao, with pus from the ears, sores on the head and face; it also treats fetal heat causing swollen and red eyes, with stools that are thick and yellow, abdominal distension and cries, as well as red swelling on the body.
    Ingredients: Chuan Yujin, Licorice, Beiqie, Tianhuafen, Gange, Mint leaves, all in equal parts.
    Grind together into a fine powder, mix with honey to form a paste, and take 3 to 7 fen or one qian with warm water. Additionally, use mugwort leaves to brew a concentrated soup, and warm soak the feet to draw the heat downward.

    Danggui Luohuang Wan
    To treat liver and gallbladder wind-heat, with ringing in the ears, discharge of green pus, known as “tinnitus,” constipation, and yellow urine. Regular use promotes blood circulation and regulates yin and yang.
    Ingredients: Danggui, Longdancao, Chaihu, each one tael; Qingdai, Danxing, Dahuang, Luohuang, each five qian; Musk five fen; Zhiziren, Huangqin, Huanglian, Huangbo, each one tael; Muxiang two qian and five fen.
    Grind together into a fine powder, refine with honey into pills the size of small beans, and take twenty pills each time, accompanied by ginger soup.[67p]

    　　清黄散　治耳出黄脓，名曰聤耳。内有风热，外为水湿所干，酝久而成。　　防风　滑石飞，各五钱　炙草一钱　藿香叶　酒黄连各二钱　栀子酒炒，三钱　　右为末，白汤调下二钱，食后服。

    　　交感丹　治耳中疳臭，名曰伍耳。或怒气上逆，上下不得宣通，遂成聋聩。　　香附子童便浸透炒，三钱　茯神　黄连各二钱　桂心　甘菊花各一钱　　右为末，每服一钱五分，灯心汤下。[68p]

    Qing Huang San: Treats ear discharge of yellow pus, known as "Teng Ear." Caused by internal wind-heat and external dampness, it develops over time.
    Ingredients:

    • Fangfeng: 5 qian
    • Shuitong: 5 qian
    • Zhi cao: 1 qian
    • Huoxiang leaves: 2 qian
    • Jiu huanglian: 2 qian
    • Zhizi fried in wine: 3 qian

    Grind these into a powder. Mix 2 qian with warm water and take after meals.

    Qing Bai San: Treats phlegm-heat obstructing the lungs, with ear discharge of white pus, known as "Chan Ear." Also treats cough.
    Ingredients:

    • Mulberry bark fried with honey: 3 qian
    • Bone skin: 3 qian
    • Cold water stone: 3 qian
    • Licorice: 1 qian
    • Fritillaria: 2 qian
    • Tianhua fen: 1.5 qian
    • Jiu qin: 1.5 qian
    • Tianmendong: 1.5 qian

    Grind these into a powder, mix with honey water, and take after meals. Alternatively, it can be taken with a decoction of Tongcao, which is particularly effective.

    Jiao Gan Dan: Treats foul odor in the ear, known as "Wu Ear." Sometimes caused by rising anger, preventing clear passage up and down, leading to deafness.
    Ingredients:

    • Xiangfuzi soaked in children's urine and then fried: 3 qian
    • Fukushen: 2 qian
    • Huanglian: 2 qian
    • Cinnamon heart: 1 qian
    • Sweet chrysanthemum: 1 qian

    Grind these into a powder. Take 1.5 qian with lampwick decoction.[68p]

    Yuyuliang Pills: For treating purulent ear discharge.
    Take Yuyuliang calcined with vinegar seven times, sea turtle shell without its backbone, and frost from hundred herbs, along with two and a half qian of each, and one raw piece of peeled and navel-less Aconite. Grind these into a powder, wrap it in cotton the size of a round walnut, and place it inside the ear, changing it twice a day. If it does not heal, then there is a worm.

    Dragon Bone Powder: For treating any purulent ear.
    One qian each of burnt alum, dragon bone, and rouge seed, with a little musk. Grind to a fine powder, wrap it on a stick, wipe away the pus in the ear, and blow one character into the ear daily. Use twice a day. Adding one qian of sea turtle shell enhances the effect.

    Sheep Horn Powder: For treating ear discharge that does not dry up.
    Burned goat horn made into powder. Every time, blow in two to three fen of the powder, twice a day for three days for full recovery.

    Nourishing Yin Di Huang Pills: For treating ear ringing due to deficiency, with wet discharge and insufficient kidney Yin.
    One liang of cooked Rehmannia root, four qian each of white Poria, peony root, and sweet chrysanthemum flower, and three times steamed black He Shou Wu mixed with yellow bitter wine. Five qian of cornelian cherry. Grind these into a powder, and refine with honey into pills the size of walnuts, taking 30 to 50 pills per dose.

    Bailian Powder: For treating sores on children's frozen ears, which may itch or hurt.
    Half a liang each of yellow bitter and Bailian.[69p]

    　　右为末，先以汤洗疮，后用生油调涂。

    Here is the translated text:

    First, wash the wound with decoction, and then apply the raw oil for treatment.

    Viburnum decoction: Treats internal heat, causing purulent discharge from the ears.
    Ingredients: Equal parts of Cimicifuga, Akebia, Ophiopogon, Red Peony, Fresh Rehmannia, Peucedanum, Sweet Chrysanthemum, Licorice, Mulberry Bark, Red Poria, and Viburnum.
    Method: Boil with ginger and jujube water, and take after meals.

    Bailong powder (also known as Xiangfan powder): Treats children with kidney excess and heat, causing heat to rise to the ears and fluids to stagnate, resulting in purulent discharge. This can also occur due to bathing water entering the ears, leading to damp accumulation that builds heat; it is referred to as ear infection. If not healed over time, it can lead to deafness.
    Ingredients: Half a tael each of dried white alum, yellow lead, and dragon bone, plus one qian of musk.
    Method: Grind to a fine powder, first use a cotton stick to clear out the purulent fluid from the ears, then use the powder to sprinkle into both ears twice a day, ensuring no wind enters.

    Modified Xiaoyao powder: Treats children's liver fire, causing ear deafness.
    Ingredients: One qian of Angelica, roasted Licorice, stir-fried Peony, Poria, roasted Atractylodes, and Chaihu, plus seven fen each of Peony and stir-fried Gardenia.
    Method: Boil with water and take.

    Modified Qingwei powder: Treats excess heat from milk accumulation in nursing mothers causing children’s deafness or ringing in the ears.
    Ingredients: Five fen of Cimicifuga, three fen each of Fresh Rehmannia, Peony, stir-fried Coptis, Angelica, Chaihu, and Gardenia.
    Method: Boil with water and take.[70p]

    　　加味归脾汤　治脾经郁结，致耳为患。　　人参　黄芪　茯神　甘草　白朮炒　远志　枣仁　龙眼肉　当归　丹皮　山栀炒，各一钱　木香五分　　右，水煎服。

    　　乌麝汤 【《卫生总微》，下同】 　治小儿风邪入耳，致令耳聋。　　大川乌头一个，重二钱以上者，以猪脂油煎令燥烈，削了面上块子，只刮皮尽，切碎，杵罗为细末　通草半两，薄切作片子，片片相似，以糯米粉作稀糊，拌匀焙干，杵罗为细末　　右二味，入麝香末少许，研匀，每服一钱，水一小盏，入薄荷二叶，枣一枚，煎数沸，放温服；或只以温酒调服。
    　　菖蒲圆　治耳聋。
    　　菖蒲一寸　巴豆一粒，去皮心
    　　右二物，合杵为剂，分作七丸，用一粒绵裹塞耳中，一日一易。　　又方
    　　菖蒲末一分　杏仁半两汤浸，去皮尖双仁者　　右二件，合杵如泥，每服用一麻子许，绵子裹，内耳中，一日一易。[71p]

    Modified Guipi Decoction: Treats stagnation in the spleen channel that causes ear ailments. Ingredients: Ginseng, Astragalus, Poria, Licorice, Fried Atractylodes, Polygala, Jujube seed, Longan flesh, Angelica, Red peony, Fried Gardenia, each one qian; Wood incense, five fen. Prepare with water and take.

    Wushe Decoction: Treats children's wind pathogen entering the ear, leading to deafness. Use one large piece of Aconite (over two qian), fry in pig fat oil until dry and intense; remove outer lumps, peel, chop finely, and grind into a fine powder. Half a liang of Tongcao, sliced thinly into similar pieces, mix with glutinous rice flour to make a thin paste, blend well, dry, and grind into a fine powder. Combine the two powders, add a little Musk powder, mix well. For each dose: one qian, with one small cup of water, add two leaves of mint and one jujube, boil a few times, let cool, and take; or mix with warm wine.

    Acorus Pills: Treats deafness. Ingredients: One inch of Acorus, one peeled and pitted Bean. Grind together into a paste, divide into seven pills, and insert one pill wrapped in cotton into the ear. Change daily.

    Another formula: One fen of Acorus powder, half a liang of Almond soaked in broth, peeled and pitted. Grind together into a paste; for each dose, take a small amount wrapped in cotton and insert into the ear. Change daily.[71p]

    　　萆麻膏　治耳聋。
    　　萆麻子十枚去皮　枣肉七枚
    　　右同研为膏，每用蕤核许，绵裹内耳，一日一易。
    　　龙朱散　治其中肿，及生疮出脓汁，或只痒痛嘘鸣，应耳中一切诸病，悉皆主之。　　龙脑一字　朱砂一钱　竹箭干内蚛虫粪三钱　坯子胭脂半钱　麝香一字　　右各研细末，和匀，以干耳子挑药入病耳中。如有脓水者，先以新绵捻子搌之凈尽，方倾入药。每夜临卧时一次。
    　　龙黄散 【《婴童百问》，下同】 　治小儿聤耳，汁出不止。　　枯矾　龙骨煅　黄丹炒，各半两　麝香研，一钱　　右同研细，先以绵杖子，捻却其中脓水，用一字掺入耳内，但用之勿令风入。

    Baimu ointment treats deafness.

    Ten peeled seeds of Baimu and seven pieces of jujube flesh, grind them together into a paste. Use a small amount to wrap in cotton and place in the inner ear, changing daily.

    Longzhu powder treats swelling and sores that produce pus, or simply itching and pain in the ears, addressing all ear conditions.

    One character of longan resin, one qian of cinnabar, three qian of bamboo arrowworm droppings, half a qian of raw rouge, one character of musk. Grind these into fine powder, mix evenly, and use a dry cotton wisp to apply the medicine into the affected ear. If there is pus, first clean it thoroughly with a fresh cotton wisp before applying the medicine, once every night before bed.

    Longhuang powder treats children’s deafness with constant pus discharge.

    Equal parts of dry alum, calcined dragon bone, and roasted yellow earth, half a liang each, and one qian of ground musk. Grind them together finely, use a cotton swab to clean out the pus, and put a small quantity into the ear, being careful to prevent wind from entering.

    Dry rouge ointment treats children’s deafness with persistent pus discharge.

    Equal parts of dry rouge, white dragon bone, calcined white alum, and white resin, ground into powder. Mix with jujube flesh to make balls the size of jujube pits, wrapped in cotton and placed into the ear, changing three times daily.[72p]

    Gold Leaf Powder
    Dried alum and rouge, each half a tael, and gold leaf.
    Grind them together until uniform and fine. Use a small amount in the ear three to four times a day.

    Dragon Bone Powder - for treating pus in the ear.
    Calcined alum and calcined dragon bone, each two qian; fried yellow lead, one and a half qian; rouge, one qian; musk, one fen, ground into fine powder. First, use cotton to wipe away pus; then blow the medicine into the ear with a goose feather tube. Adding powdered sea turtle shell is particularly effective.

    Formula for Hearing Loss due to Wind Heat in Children (from "Sheng Hui Fang")
    Remove the heart from the artemisia; licorice roasted until slightly charred; bupleurum, and sweet flag, each one fen; magnetite, three fen, crushed and rinsed to remove red juice; strip the heart from the ophiopogon and roast, half a tael. Grind all the ingredients finely and sieve to make a powder. Each dose is mixed with scallion white soup and taken at half a qian, twice a day, adjusting according to the child's size as needed.

    Tongming Powder - Zhang Huan's formula for treating deafness.
    Sweet flag, one inch (nine sections); remove the heart from the artemisia; each one tael; bupleurum, ophiopogon without heart, and siler, each half a tael; asarum cleaned of soil, and sweet wormwood, each one fen. Grind all these into extremely fine powder, then add one fen of magnetite, prepared as before; fourteen apricot kernels, soaked in soup, peeled and ground. Mix all ingredients evenly; each dose is half a qian, cooked in scallion white soup and taken twice a day after meals.[73p]

    Xixin Ointment
    From the "Sacred Benefit Formulas"
    Used to treat children's deafness, whether due to heat in the brain, water entering, or due to exposure to wind, this should be applied.
    Ingredients:

    • Xixin (Asari)
    • Fangfeng (Siler)
    • Chuan Dahuang (Chinese rhubarb), lightly roasted
    • Huangqin (Scutellaria) – each one part
    • Chuan Jiao (Chinese pepper) – ten pieces
    • Wax – half a tael

    Prepare the above ingredients finely powdered. Boil with three cups of pure sesame oil, strain through a purple cloth, add the wax and wait for it to dissolve into ointment. Apply a large soybean-sized dot into the ear three times a day.

    Formula for Persistent Deafness in Children

    • Sweet Stinkweed
    • Almonds, soaked and peeled
    • Salt – equal parts

    Crush the above ingredients into a paste. Mix with a small amount of pig fat, boil until thick, and wrap in cotton, the size of a jujube pit, to plug the ear. Change daily.

    Another formula

    • Pine resin
    • Acorus powder
    • Black sesame oil – each half a tael

    Mix the above ingredients thoroughly, crush well, and wrap in cotton. Plug the ear with a piece the size of a red bean, once daily.

    Yet another formula

    • Mustard seeds, crushed into a paste

    Mix with human milk, wrap a small amount in cotton, and plug the ear. Change daily.

    • Two pennies of galls

    Chao Wu San: For treating children's ear tinnitus that does not stop day and night. Take equal parts of Chao Pu and Wu Dou, each four parts. Grind them into a powder, then wrap in cotton and place inside the ear, twice a day.

    Hong Yu San (Tian Family Formula): For treating children's ear ringing. Take equal parts of dried alum, musk, and dry dye. Grind the ingredients together, first clean the ear of pus with a cotton stick, then mix in a small amount.

    Long Huang San (Tang Family Formula): For treating ear ringing. Take half a tael each of dried alum, dragon bone, and yellow lead, and one qian each of musk and yellow bracken. Grind into a powder, clean the pus, and insert into the ear.

    Fan Xiang San (from "Total Essentials of Hygiene"): For treating ear ringing. One tael of white alum, burnt to ash; one fen of snake bed seeds, ground into powder. Mix well, then add five fen of musk powder, grind fine, using a dose each time to insert into the affected ear.

    Musk Powder: For treating ear ringing. One spider, half a qian of dye, and half a character of musk. All ingredients must be very dry, ground into a fine powder. Use half a dose to gently blow into the ear with a goose feather pipe.

    Jian Meng San: For treating ear ringing. Take two qian each of Lian Xiao flower, sea snail, dye, and excrement of bamboo infested with worms, along with one character of musk. Grind them together into a fine powder, mix well. Each time, first clean the ear of pus with a cotton stick, then use a paper twist dipped in medicine to apply into the ear, three times a day.[75p]

    Red Cotton Powder for Treating Earache
    Red cotton, three qian; arsenic, one qian; musk, a small amount. Grind these together, mix thoroughly with a spoon, using cotton to roll and blend. For use, take a similar amount of yellow millet and insert it into the ear. If ulcers or pus form around the ear, apply this mixture directly onto the wound, cover it with paper, and it works wonders.

    Oil-Infused Powder for Treating Earache
    One pair of male and female stone燕 (yàn), bake in a brick bowl over charcoal fire until white, grind into powder; divide equal parts of red lead and powder from the fatty masses, adding a small amount of musk. Mix well. First, use cotton to wipe the pus out of the ear, then lie on your side and insert a small amount of the medicine into the ear. With one drop of oil, it will take effect immediately.

    Cotton Wrapped Powder for Treating Earache
    One part cinnamon, one part sheep dung, fry until it changes color. Grind these together, using a small amount to wrap in cotton and plug into the ear.

    Red and Blue Flower Powder for Chronic Earache
    Wash and dry red and blue flowers and prepare equal amounts of yellow berberine; half amounts of dried yellow qin and fishbone. Grind all four ingredients together into a fine powder, then use half a liang of finely ground musk with water. Mix everything well, then wrap in cotton and place inside the ear, replacing it twice daily.

    Recipe for Ear Pain
    Prepare equal amounts of peeled and processed aconite and calamus, and use them to plug the ear.[76p]

    Huanming Drink: Treats children who are unable to see at night, known as "sparrow eyes." Ingredients: Night Bright Sand, Well Water Sand, Valley Essence Grass, Clam Powder—each in equal parts.     He Ming Powder: Treats children's "sparrow eyes," leading to night blindness. Grind into a powder, then mix with honey to form pills the size of a tung seed. Take seventy pills at a time, swallowed with salty warm water on an empty stomach.

Grind into a powder, mix with honey to form pills the size of a tung seed. Take seventy pills at a time, swallowed with hot water, without regard to timing.

    Di Huang San
    Used for treating children with heat accumulation in the heart and liver, leading to red, swollen, painful eyes, or internal red veins, or white membranes covering the eyes; if the condition spreads around the eyes, it can still be easily treated; however, if it suddenly covers the black part of the eyes, it may lead to blindness, so this formula should be used promptly. It also treats eye issues from sores or rashes.

    Sheng Di Huang 30g
    Shu Di Huang 30g
    Chan Tui, without head and feet 25g
    Mu Zei 25g
    Gu Jing Cao 25g
    Sheng Xi Mo, powdered 25g
    Dang Gui 25g

    Fang Feng 15g
    Qiang Huo 15g
    Bai Ji Li, thorns removed 15g
    Sheng Gan Cao 10g
    Sha Yuan Ji Li 10g
    Mu Tong 10g
    Huang Lian, bearded part removed 10g
    Da Huang, lightly prepared 10g
    Yuan Shen 5g

    Grind the above into a fine powder. Each time, take a grain or half a grain (for dosage), depending on the person's size, adjust accordingly. Decoct with lamb liver soup and take after meals, three times a day. Avoid speaking during the treatment. This also treats adults.[81p]

    Comprehensive Medical Collection, Volume 413: Diseases of Children’s Head, Face, Ears, Eyes, and Nose

    Formulas

    Lifesaving Eye Drops: To remove cloudiness and alleviate pain.

    • Ingredients: 2 qian of Angelica, 2 qian of Huanglian, 2.5 qian of Fangfeng, 0.5 qian of Xixin, 1 qian of Licorice.
    • Preparation: Add these to 1 large bowl of water, boil with gentle fire until it does not disperse in water; then add a small amount of prepared honey for use.

    Thousand Gold Liver Supplement Powder: For loss of vision.

    • Ingredients: 1 lamb’s liver (cleaned and thinly sliced), dried over a new tile, 0.5 qian of Jue Ming Zi, and 1 he of Polygala, boiled until fragrant.
    • Preparation: Grind into powder, take 1 pinch each time, twice daily; efficacy noted over time.

    Fundamental Formula: For obstruction and cloudy membrane causing vision blockage due to cold water at the Taiyang point.

    • Ingredients: 1 liang each of Fangfeng and Bai Jizhi, 2.5 qian of Qiang Huo, 3 liang of sweet chrysanthemum.
    • Preparation: Grind into powder, take 2 qian with a little salt, consumed with boiling water.

    Lifesaving Antelope Horn Powder: For long-term ice blindness.

    • Ingredients: Equal parts of Antelope Horn, Sheng Ma, and Xixin, half the amount of Licorice.
    • Preparation: Grind into powder; form half into pills the size of a tung seed (5 to 70 pills per dose); the other half boiled in water for taking with pills. Also used for treating opacity caused by dampness. If heat and yin deficiency are present, it can be used with the Immortal's Cloud-Dispersing Pills.[87p]

    　　东垣补阳汤　治阳不胜其阴，乃阴盛阳虚，则九窍不通，令青白翳见于大眦，乃足太阳少阴经中郁，遏厥阴肝经之阳气，不得上通于目，故青翳内阻也。当于太阳少阴经中，是九泉之下，以益肝中阳气，冲天上行。此乃先补其阳，后于足太阴标中泻足厥阴之火，下伏于阳中。《内经》曰：阴盛阳虚。则当先补其阳，后泻其阴。每日空心服升阳汤，临卧服泻阴丸。须预期调养，体气和平，天气晴明服之，补其阳使上升通于肝经之末，利空窍于目矣。　　羌活　独活　当归身酒洗焙干　甘草梢　熟地黄　人参　黄芪　白朮各一两　泽泻　橘红各半两　生地　白茯　知母炒黄，各三钱　柴胡二两　防风　白芍各五钱　肉桂一钱　　右，每服五钱，水煎空心服。候药力行尽，方可饮食也。[88p]

    Dongyuan Buyang Decoction is used to treat conditions in which yang cannot overcome yin, leading to an excess of yin and a deficiency of yang. This imbalance results in obstruction of the nine orifices, causing blue and white cataracts to appear at the corners of the eyes. The yin obstructs the flow of yang from the foot Taiyang and Shaoyin meridians, preventing it from ascending to the eyes, hence the internal blockage of blue cataracts. It is important to supplement the yang first and then drain the fire of the foot Jueyin from the foot Taiyin meridian, rooted in the yang.

    The Neijing states: When yin is excessive and yang is deficient, one should first supplement yang and then drain yin. Take Shengyang Decoction on an empty stomach daily, and before bed, take a draining yin pill. Anticipate adjustments and nurturing of the body’s energy, maintaining equilibrium of body energy and clarity of external conditions while taking this decoction. This will help to supplement yang, allowing it to rise and flow to the end of the liver meridian, thus benefiting the open orifices of the eyes.

    The ingredients include: Qianghuo, Duhuo, Danggui (washed and dried in wine), Licorice stalks, Shudihuang, Ren Shen, Huangqi, Baizhu, each one tael; Zexie and Ju Hong, each half a tael; Shengdi, Bai Fu Ling, and Zhimu, each three qian; Chaihu two taels; Fangfeng and Baishao, each five qian; and Rougui one qian.

    Prepare five qian for each dose, decocting with water and taking it on an empty stomach. Once the medicinal effect has been fully achieved, then one may eat and drink.[88p]

    Qianfu Wuxiu Chongming Pills
    Treats eye ailments such as clouding, obscured vision, and dim sight. Regular use benefits the head and eyes.

    Ingredients:

    • 500 pieces of sweet chrysanthemum
    • 500 spikes of vitex
    • 500 stems of horsetail
    • 500 pieces of paper mulberry seeds

    Grind these into a fine powder, mix with honey to form pills the size of a tung seed. Take 50 pills each time, dissolved in warm water.

    Harmony and Stomach Nourishing Decoction
    Treats the initial onset of internal ailments, slight dimming of vision, seeing black spots in the air, with watery vision turning light green; next, vision blurs, seeing double, with watery vision turning light white; if prolonged, vision may be lost, with watery vision turning pure white.

    Ingredients:

    • 7 qian of bupleurum
    • 1 liang each of ginseng, angelica, roasted licorice, dried ginger, asarum, kudzu root, white atractylodes, and qinghao
    • 5 qian of fine wind
    • 1.5 liang of astragalus
    • 3 qian of white poria
    • 6 qian of white peony
    • 2 qian of schisandra

    Grind and take 2 qian with water decocted.

    Nourishing Yin Kidney Qi Pills
    Treats watery vision that becomes gradually more obscured as if walking in fog, seeing black spots in the air, and double vision. Prolonged conditions may lead to loss of vision with watery vision becoming light white.

    • 3 liang of cooked rehmannia
    • Tail of angelica
    • Peony bark
    • Schisandra
    • Dried yam
    • Bupleurum (5 qian each)
    • Poria and alisma (2.5 qian each)

    Grind these into a fine powder, mix with honey to form pills the size of a tung seed, coated with cinnabar. Take 10 pills each time, dissolved in warm water.[90p]

    Chaihu Fusheng Decoction treats red eyes with a sensitivity to light, excessive tears, little discharge, heaviness at the crown of the head, pain in the eyes corresponding to the sun, weak eyelashes, a constant desire to close the eyes, sour pain from prolonged view, and cases where the haze sinks down. Ingredients: Chaihu (6 fen), Acanthopanax (2.5 fen), Ligusticum wallichii (2.5 fen), Notopterygium (2.5 fen), White Peony root (stir-fried, 2.5 fen), Honey-fried Licorice (4 fen), Mint (4 fen), Platycodon (4 fen), Schisandra (12 grains, ground), Atractylodes (5 fen), Poria (5 fen), Huang Qin (stir-fried, 5 fen). Each dose is 2 qian, decocted in water and taken after meals.

    Huanglian Yanggan Pill treats red eyes with a very strong pulse and discharge. The ingredients consist of ground Huanglian and one piece of white goat liver. First, scrape the goat liver with a bamboo knife until it becomes a paste, remove the sinews, then grind it finely into Huanglian, forming pills the size of a tung seed. Take ten pills each time, washed down with clear tea.

    Xiao Chaihu Decoction treats children whose eyes are swollen and reddened with pain, suffering greatly day and night. Ingredients include equal parts: Chaihu, Ginseng, Huangqin, Honey-fried Licorice, and Banxia. Adjust the dosage according to the child's size, decoct in water and administer. If prolonged dizziness occurs, remove Banxia and add Dahuang, bamboo leaves, and raw Rehmannia.[91p]

    Bai Jie San

    For treating children with photophobia, swollen eyelids, slight purplish discoloration, constipation or diarrhea, and either dark or clear urine.

    Ingredients:

    • Kudzu root
    • Cimicifuga (Shengma)
    • Red peony
    • Scutellaria baicalensis
    • Ephedra (prepared with wine)
    • Thinly peeled cinnamon
    • Licorice (equal parts)

    Preparation: Grind the above ingredients, take 6 grams each time, add one cup of water, simmer until reduced by a third, and drink warm at any time. If there is significant wind-heat, add mint and simmer together.

    For treating the same conditions.

    • Northern asarum

    Preparation: Grind into a powder, mix with honey to make pills the size of a nut, and take ten with tea on an empty stomach.

    Liang Ge San

    Qingwei Powder 【"Introduction to Medicine"】
    For treating children's wind-strings and rotten eyes, with accumulated heat in the diaphragm.
    Equal parts of: Shengma (clematis), Sheng Di Huang (rehmannia root), Dan Pi (moutan bark), Chao Huang Lian (fried coptis), and Dang Gui (angelica root).
    Prepare by decocting in water. If adding Chai Hu (bupleurum) and Shan Zhi (gardenia), it becomes the modified Qingwei Powder.

    Xiegan Powder 【"Jade Secrets"】
    For the same condition.
    Equal parts of: Mu Zei (horsetail), Wei Ling Xian (clematis), Zi Shen (purple ginseng), Ju Hua (chrysanthemum), Qiang Huo (notopterygium), Chan Tui (cicada slough), Sheng Da Huang (raw rhubarb), Zhi Gan Cao (honey-fried licorice), and Shi Jue Ming (shell of abalone).
    A little brain matter.
    Grind all into a powder, using two qian (a form of measurement) of the medicine with one liang (a larger measurement) of pig liver, removing the membrane, stuffing the medicine inside, tying it up, and then boiling in rice water until cooked and chewing down.

    Rui Ren Paste 【"Standards for Diagnosis and Treatment", the same here】
    Forty-nine Rui Ren (prunella) seeds, remove the skin and extract the oil.
    A little brain matter.
    Grind into a paste, using a small amount lit with a lampwick.

    Lingyuan Antelope Horn Pills
    For treating children's liver and lung heat accumulation, with flesh growing in the eye, red veins causing pain; also for red eyes with obstruction, eye pain, itching, and sensitivity to light; as well as for wind sores and effective eye treatment.
    Crushed and dried antelope horn, Sheng Gan Cao (raw licorice), Bai He Shou Wu (white fo-ti), and Wa Song (periploca) cleaned of soil, each one liang; Sheng Gan Di Huang (raw rehmannia) washed, and Yu Jin (curcuma) roasted to expel fire, each two liang.
    Mix these six ingredients, finely shred, dry, pound, and sieve into a fine powder. Refine with honey into pills the size of mung beans, taking seven to ten pills each time.[93p]

    Tan's method is uniquely effective in treating children's eye conditions, with symptoms like frequent crying and discomfort.

    For the Pig Gallbladder and Coptis Pills:
    This treats children's eye conditions with white membranes covering the eyes, particularly when other medicines have failed.

    Ingredients include equal parts of:

    • Hu Huanglian (胡黄连),
    • Realgar (雄黄),
    • Night shining sand (夜明砂) finely ground.

    Several pig gallbladders and a small amount of musk (麝香) not cooked with the gall.

    Grind together the powders using the pig gall juice to adjust the consistency. Pack this mixture into the gall bladder, tightly secured with thread, and boil in rice wash water for five to seven boils. Remove and cool. Grind the musk finely in a mortar and then combine with the medicinal powder, omitting the gall bladder. Form small pills the size of a hemp seed, taking ten pills per dose, increasing up to fifteen for larger patients, swallowed with rice drink. If liver qi is strong, use aged rice drink instead.

    Xixin Powder: Treats excessive heat in the heart, causing red and swollen eyes.
    Ingredients: 1 tael of Ephedra (removing the root), 1.5 taels of prepared Rhubarb, 1.5 taels of Schizonepeta (head), and 0.5 taels of raw Licorice.
    Preparation: Grind finely. Each dose is half a qian or one character, mixed with honey water to take.

    Xigan Powder: Treats obstructive heat in the Sanjiao, causing red and swollen eyes, and excessive tearing.
    Ingredients: 1 fen of Peony, 0.5 fen of Qiang Huo, 1 fen of Siler and its branches, and 0.5 fen each of Rhubarb and Licorice.
    Preparation: Grind finely. For infants, use one character; for children aged two to three, half a qian; for adults, one qian, boiled in half a bowl of water with a small amount of lamp wick and black beans, consumed after cooling post-meal. Boil in silver or stone mortar and alternate with Sishun Powder, applying a cooling balm on the temples.

    Sishun Powder: Treats red and swollen eyes.
    Ingredients: Wash and roast Dong Quai, equal parts of red Peony, Rhubarb (wrapped in paper), and roasted Licorice.
    Preparation: Grind finely. Each dose is one qian, boiled in one bowl of water until reduced to half a bowl, strain and take warm. Adjust dosage as needed.

    Cooling Balm: Treats red, swollen, and painful eyes, applied to the temples.
    Ingredients: Leaves of Hibiscus, harvested after the first day of autumn, dried in the shade and ground into a powder.
    Preparation: Each dose is one character or half a qian, mixed with well water, applied to the temples.

    Yuanjingshi Powder: Treats the appearance of red veins in the eyes.[96p]

    Yuanjing stone, one tael; licorice, half a tael.

    Qiangju powder treats eye floaters and membranes obstructing vision.
    Qianghuo and purified chrysanthemum, half a tael; Fangfeng and branches, each one-fraction; remove the shell from two-fractions of zhizhi, stir-fry; licorice, one and a half fractions, stir-fry; white spiny thistle, half a tael, stir-fry to remove spikes.     Jue Ming pills treat the same conditions.
    Select clean Jue Ming seeds; plantago seeds; purified chrysanthemum; Chuanxiong; Xuanlian; and cleaned angelica, each one fraction; da huang and huang qin, each half fraction. Grind these into a fine powder, and blend with honey to form pills the size of sesame seeds.     Huangbai Ointment by the Qian Family

    This protects the eyes and can prevent the toxicity of smallpox from entering.
    One tael of Huangbai, two taels of ground mung beans, three taels of raw licorice.
    Grind these into a fine powder, mix with sesame oil to make an ointment, and apply it four to five times to the area in front of the ears, the corners of the eyes, and below the eyes. If applied early, the appearance of smallpox will be mild. If the eyes are already afflicted, applying it will help to alleviate the condition.

    The world traditionally recognizes Cao Zhuo powder for treating eye conditions.

    For the Cao Zhuo powder, use four taels of Cao Zhuo, soaked in rice wash, sliced, and roasted. This is ground into a fine powder. Take two taels of pig liver, opened and mixed with the powder inside, bound with hemp, combined with one he of millet and one bowl of water, then cooked in a sand pot until done and used to steam the eyes. Wait until warm, and take three qian before lying down; it is highly effective.

    For pig hoof shell powder, which treats children's rashes affecting the eyes: take two taels of pig hoof shell, and burn in salt mud until charred and ground to a powder. Remove soil from cicada shells and grind them into powder. Additionally, one tael of antelope horn should be ground into a fine powder.

    Mix the previous two ingredients and add one part of ground antelope horn. Each time, use a character's worth, with children over a hundred days old taking half a qian, and those over three years taking three qian, mixed with fresh or warm water, three to four times a day and one or two times at night. Treatment becomes difficult after a year.

    Another prescription, for ear treatment, uses one qian of cinnabar and eight fen of powder frost, ground into a fine powder and stirred with a little water. Use a spoon to drop one or two points into the ear. Additionally, use: white chrysanthemum, bean skin, valley herb, and night shining sand, ground into a powder.

    Boil these four ingredients into a paste with half a bowl of rice wash, strain it, then add ten or more dried persimmons and continue cooking. Eat two or three daily and drink the boiled persimmon soup.

    Another formula treats children's rashes affecting the eyes.[101p]

    Golden Wave Dispersion

    For the treatment of red, swollen, painful eyes from seasonal illnesses, with heat and excessive tears:

    • Huanglian (Coptis root) 1 liang
    • Pengsha (realgar)
    • Hanshuishi (cold water stone) 2 qian each
    • Dahuang (rhubarb) 2 qian
    • Haipiaoxiao (sea horse)
    • Tongqing (green copper) 1 qian each
    • Yuanming powder 2 qian 5 fen
    • Quanxie (scorpion) 7 pieces, spine and venom removed
    • Musk 1 character

    Except for Yuanming powder and musk, the remaining seven ingredients should be finely ground and dried, then added to the Yuanming powder and musk in a mortar, and thoroughly mixed. For each use, take a character to half a qian, dissolve in warm soup or cool water, clarify and strain, and wash frequently without interruption. For itching caused by wind and parasites, use Qingfen (light powder) for effect. Avoid alcohol and meat for three to five days.

    Huanglian Ointment

    For the treatment of seasonal fiery eye ailments, characterized by redness, swelling, painful sensations, and constant agitation day and night:

    • Clean Huanglian 2 qian 5 fen

    Finely grind the above, use one egg to extract the essence, place in a clay bowl, mix in Huanglian, ferment for a while until yellow appears, then filter through silk to obtain the ointment. The patient should lie on their back, and someone should place a bit into the eye frequently until a bitter taste is sensed in the mouth, indicating the medication has taken effect. This is also effective for residual toxins from smallpox attacking the eyes, particularly in heat conditions.[104p]

    　　速效饮　治长成小儿，因他物或跌着触损，两目血胀肿痛。　　荆芥穗　薄荷叶微炒　草决明微炒，各一两　甘草三钱，生用　　右为粗末，和半生半炒芝麻等分，抄二钱，掌中盛干嚼之，味尽吐去滓，如此法投三五次，即效。[105p]

    Cool Ointment: Treats violent redness, fiery swelling and pain in the eyes, as well as painful and heated blood boils. Ingredients: 1 tael each of rhubarb, purified coptis, berberine, red root, fine xixin, mint leaves, and calcined nitre. Grind the first six ingredients into a fine powder, then mix with calcined nitre in a stone mortar until uniform. Use 1 to 2 qian of this mixture, diluted in cold water mixed with ginger juice for external application to the solar plexus, or use freshly drawn well water for better effect. For hot boils, dilute with cool rice soup and apply to the affected area.

    Dust Repelling Ointment: Treats children’s eyes irritated by dust, causing swelling, heat, and pain, leading to incessant crying. Ingredients: Oil smoke, finely ground ink, and concentrated freshly drawn well water, mixed with half a qian of yuanming powder to form an ointment. Apply with a brush to the eye three to five times for immediate effect. Also, avoid drinking alcohol for a day and night.

    Quick Effect Drink: Treats children who have been injured by external force or falling, leading to blood swelling and pain in both eyes. Ingredients: 1 tael each of schizonepeta spike, lightly roasted mint leaves, and lightly roasted cassia seeds, along with 3 qian of raw licorice. Grind into a coarse powder and mix half raw and half roasted sesame. Take 2 qian of this mixture in the palm, chew thoroughly, and spit out any residue. Repeat this method three to five times for immediate effect.[105p]

    　　菊睛丸 【《局方》】 　治脾肾不足，眼花昏暗。　　枸杞子　苁蓉酒浸炒　巴戟去心，各一两　甘菊花四两　　右为末，蜜丸梧子大，每服十丸，空心白汤化下。
    　　复明散 【《证治准绳》，下同】 　治小儿每至日暮即不见物，乃雀目也。　　苍朮米泔浸，刮去皮，銼焙干，二两　谷精草一两　地肤子　决明子　黄芩各半两　　右件捣罗为细末，每服一钱，水八分，入荆芥少许，煎五分，去滓温服，食后。

    Jujing Pill
    For treating spleen and kidney deficiency with blurred vision.
    Ingredients:

    • 1 tael of Goji berries
    • 1 tael of roasted Cynomorium (soaked in wine)
    • 1 tael of Ba Ji (without heart)
    • 4 taels of sweet chrysanthemum flowers
      Grind the above into a powder, form into pills the size of a wutou (small chestnut). Take 10 pills each time, dissolved in warm water on an empty stomach.

    Fumingsan
    For treating children who cannot see objects at dusk, known as "sparrow eye".
    Ingredients:

    • 2 taels of Cang Zhu (prepared with rice water, peeled, and dried)
    • 1 tael of Guo Jing Grass
    • 0.5 taels each of Earth Skin Seed, Cassia Seed, and Huang Qin
      Grind the above into a fine powder. Take 1 qian (3.33 grams) with 8 parts of water, add a little Jing Jie's herb, simmer for 5 minutes, strain, and drink warm after meals.

    Shanzhuyu Pill
    For treating excessive white in children's eyes due to deficiency.
    Ingredients:

    • 2 taels of Shan Zha Yu (Cornus)
    • 1 tael each of cooked Rehmannia, Dan Pi (Cortex Moutan), Niu Xi (Achyranthes), Fu Ling, and Ze Xie
    • 0.5 taels of deer antler
      Grind the above into a powder, refine with honey to form pills the size of a wutou. Take 20 pills with warm saline after meals.

    Longdandelution
    For treating eye pus and corneal opacity due to damp-heat. Highly effective but not for treating cold-heat diseases.
    Ingredients:

    • 0.5 taels of clam powder
    • 0.5 taels of Guo Jing Grass
    • 3 qian (10 grams) each of Qiang Huo and Grass Dragon Dandelion
    • 2.5 qian of Ma Huang
    • 2 qian each of roasted Huang Qin and Sheng Ma
    • 5 qian each of Turmeric and Snake skin
    • 0.5 qian of fried Licorice
      Grind the above into a fine powder. Take 2 qian after meals with warm tea.[106p]

    　　真珠膏 【《证治准绳》，下同】 　专治眼病久不瘥，昏不见物。　　真珠末细研　甘菊花为末　香豉炒黄为末　井泉石细研，各二钱半　　右拌匀，白蜜一合，鲤鱼胆一枚，同药慢火熬成膏，入好龙脑一钱，同拌匀，每用少许，时时点眼中。[107p]

    Danxi's Pill for Treating Children's Eye Problems: For treating children's eye squint and redness with excessive tearing, use a powder made from gourd tops mixed with turmeric, and take this pill after vomiting.

    Ingredients:

    • Raw rhubarb: 2 taels
    • Gansui: 1 tael
    • Euphorbia: 1 tael
    • Wine amaranth: 1 tael
    • Green peel: 1 tael
    • Aged tangerine peel: 1 tael
    • Cowherb head powder: 4 taels
    • Wood fragrance: 0.5 tael

    Grind the above ingredients into a fine powder, make pills the size of a Chinese jujube, and take 60-70 pills each time with warm water, adjusting according to the symptoms.

    Jingquanshi Powder by Zhang Huan: For treating eye pathogens caused by heat, which gradually leads to cataracts and harms the sight, use this formulation.

    Ingredients:

    • Jingquanshi: 1 tael
    • Shijue Ming: 0.5 tael
    • Sweet chrysanthemum flower: 0.5 tael
    • Night brightness sand, lightly toasted: 0.5 tael
    • Huanglian, beard removed: 0.5 tael
    • Late silkworm sand, lightly toasted: 0.5 tael

    Crush and sieve the ingredients into a fine powder. Take 1 qian using a bowl of rice water, add a small amount of fresh pig liver, simmer for five minutes until the liver is well done, allow it to cool, and take regularly after meals.

    Pearl Paste: This is specifically for long-standing eye ailments that do not heal, leading to blurred vision.

    Ingredients:

    • Pearl powder: 2.5 qian
    • Sweet chrysanthemum flower powder: 2.5 qian
    • Roasted fragrant soybean powder: 2.5 qian
    • Jingquanshi, finely ground: 2.5 qian

    Mix these evenly, add 1 he of white honey, and the gallbladder of a carp, and slow-cook them into a paste. Add a measured amount of high-quality dragon brain to mix thoroughly. Take a small amount and apply it to the eyes as needed.[107p]
