    Niu Huang Gao treats children's eyes for clarity.

    Take 1 qian of niu huang, 2 qian of powdered rhino horn, 1.2 qian of licorice, and 5 sheets each of gold and silver foil. Grind these into a powder, then refine with honey into pills the size of mung beans. Take 7 pills each time, washed down with mint tea.

    Tie Xuan Tong Guan Gao treats children who have been affected by the nurse's breath, causing nasal congestion and inability to suckle.

    Take 1 liang of jing jie, stir-fried xiang fu, 7.5 qian each of white silkworms and zhao jiao, 1.75 liang of chuan xiong, and 5 qian of xi xin. Grind these into fine powder, mix with crushed scallion whites, knead into cakes, and apply to the forehead.

    Huang Qin Tang treats diarrhea accompanied by headache, chest fullness, bitter mouth, and dry throat, or fluctuating chills and fevers with vomiting, characterized by a floating, strong, and wiry pulse. Specifically treats heat-related diarrhea.

    Take 1.5 liang of huang qin, 1 liang of shao yao, and 0.5 liang of honey-fried licorice. Grind these into powder. For each dose, take 3 qian with one jujube, boil in one cup of water until reduced by a third, strain and drink warm. For vomiting, add 1.2 qian of ban xia and 3 slices of fresh ginger.[108p]

    　　薄荷汤　治乳下婴儿鼻塞不通，及治夹惊伤寒。　　薄荷叶半两　羌活　全蝎　甘草　麻黄去节　僵蚕炒去丝嘴　天竺黄　白附子各一钱半　　右为末，薄荷汤下。热极生风，加竹沥少许，与服。一方有柴胡、苔芎、桔梗、茯苓，无全蝎、僵蚕、天竺黄、白附子。
    　　消风散　治诸风上攻，头目昏痛，项背拘急，肢体烦疼，肌肉蠕动，目眩旋晕，耳作蝉鸣，眼濇好睡，鼻塞多嚏，皮肤顽麻，瘙疮瘾疹，小儿虚风，目濇昏困。　　白茯苓　川芎藭　羌活　荆芥穗　防风　藿香叶　白僵蚕炒　蝉蜕去土　甘草炙　厚朴姜炒　陈皮去白，各一两　　右为细末，每服半钱，茶清调下，薄荷汤亦可。急慢惊风，乳香、荆芥汤调下。或加雄黄，名雄黄散。[109p]

    Peppermint Decoction is used to treat nasal congestion in infants and to address conditions caused by fright and cold. The ingredients include half a tael of peppermint leaves, a tael each of Qianghuo, scorpion, licorice, and Ma Huang (with the stalks removed), as well as a tael and a half each of Jiangcan (silkworm, toasted and without silk), Tianzhu Huang, and Bai Fuzhi. Grind these into a fine powder and mix with the peppermint decoction. If there is extreme heat causing wind, add a small amount of bamboo juice to take with it. Another recipe includes Chai Hu, Tai Chong, Jie Geng, and Fu Ling, but it omits the scorpion, Jiangcan, Tianzhu Huang, and Bai Fuzhi.

    Xiao Feng San (Wind-Dispersing Powder) is used to treat various wind attacks manifesting as headache, neck stiffness, limb soreness, muscle twitching, dizziness, ear ringing, dry eyes leading to sleepiness, nasal congestion with frequent sneezing, skin numbness, itching, and for children with weak wind symptoms. The ingredients include Bai Fu Ling, Chuan Xiong, Qianghuo, JIng Jie flower spikes, Fang Feng, Huoxiang leaves, Bai Jiangcan (toasted), and cicada slough (cleaned of soil), combined with toasted licorice and Huopaliang ginger, and aged tangerine peel without white parts, each at one tael. Grind these into a fine powder, and take half a qian mixed with clear tea or peppermint decoction. For sudden or prolonged fright, use frankincense and Jing Jie decoction. Optionally, add Xiong Huang (Realgar) to create Xiong Huang San (Realgar Powder).[109p]

    　　通关散　治小儿鼻塞，惊风搐搦，关窍不通，皆由痰塞中脘，留滞百节所致。痰之所以潮塞者，气实使之。　　南星炮，一钱　麝香一字　皂角略烧存性，二钱　赤蜈蚣炙，一条　直僵蚕炒去丝嘴，一钱　　右为末，以手点姜汁蘸药少许，擦牙，或用物引滴入药二三点，涎出自开。鼻塞调敷儿顖。
    　　辛夷膏张涣　治鼻塞。
    　　辛夷叶一两，洗焙干　细幸　木通　香白芷　木香各半两，为细末　杏仁一分，泡去皮尖研　　右件用羊髓猪脂各二两，同诸药相和，于石器中慢熬成膏，赤黄色，放冷入龙脑、麝香各一钱，拌匀，每用少许涂鼻中。若乳下婴儿，乳母吹着儿顖鼻塞者，只涂顖上。[110p]

    Tong Guan San
    For treating children's nasal congestion, convulsions due to fright, and blockage of the orifices, all caused by phlegm obstructing the central cavity, which results in stagnation in the hundred joints. The reason phlegm becomes obstructive is due to the accumulation of qi.

    Ingredients:

    • Equal parts of southern star (Nanxing) powder, one qian
    • A small amount of musk, one character
    • Soap pod (Zaojiao), slightly burned to retain its nature, two qian
    • Red centipede (Chihwugong) roasted, one piece
    • Dried silkworms (Jiangcan), stir-fried to remove silk and mouthparts, one qian

    Mix these into a fine powder. Use a little ginger juice to dampen the powder and apply it to the teeth; alternatively, use a utensil to drip two or three drops of the medicine, which should help with salivation. Apply to clear the nasal congestion in the child.

    Xinyigao (Magnolia Ointment)
    For treating nasal congestion.

    Ingredients:

    • One liang of magnolia leaves, washed and dried
    • Half a liang each of fine sage, wood mullein, white angelica, and wood fragrance, all ground into a fine powder
    • One fen of apricot kernels, soaked to remove the skin and point, and ground

    Combine these with two liang each of sheep marrow and pig lard, and mix all the ingredients in a stone vessel, simmering slowly to form a yellowish-red ointment. After cooling, mix in one qian each of dragon brain (Longnao) and musk, stirring thoroughly. Use a small amount to apply inside the nose. For infants still breastfeeding, if the nurse blows into the infant's congested nose, just apply it to the forehead.[110p]

    Congxian Gao from the Gong Family: Used for children aged three to five days, who have nasal congestion and are breathless, crying continuously while feeding. Use seven strips each of pig's tooth soapberry and other ingredients, ground and mixed with the soapberry powder to form a paste, which can be applied to the bridge of the nose for healing.

    Rhinoceros Horn and Rehmannia Decoction: Used for treating nosebleeds. Ingredients: one tael of rhinoceros horn powder, one tael of peony root, eight Qian of raw dry rehmannia, and seven Qian of red peony. Take one to two Qian per dose, boiled in water for consumption.

    Rehmannia Powder (Yang's Recipe): Treats heat in the spleen, lung obstruction, and nosebleeds. Equal parts of raw rehmannia, red peony, dong quai (Chinese angelica), and chuanxiong (Sichuan lovage). Each dose is two to three Qian, boiled in water, adding a little catkins. For spring and summer nosebleeds, add a little rehmannia juice and catkins. For autumn and winter nosebleeds, use a little plantago seed juice.

    Liujunzi Decoction: Treats nosebleeds in children. Ingredients are equal parts of ginseng, white atractylodes, poria, dried tangerine peel, pinellia, and licorice. Grind into powder, taking two Qian per dose, boiled in ginger and jujube water.

    Four Substances Decoction: Treats infants with a bloated head, nosebleeds, and red color between the chin. The ingredients are one Qian each of dong quai, chuanxiong, peony, gardenia, and cooked rehmannia. Brew in water for consumption.[111p]

    Wuling San: Treatment as described above.
    Red Poria, Red Peony each 5 fen; roasted Gardenia, Angelica each 3 fen; Licorice 2 fen. Use ten lampwick stems, decoct in water for consumption.

    Huangqi Shaoyao Decoction: Treats persistent nosebleeds over the years, with a sallow complexion and dry eyes, excessive tearing and hand numbness.
    Huangqi 3 liang; roasted Licorice, Asarum, Kudzu, and Qianghuo each 1 liang; fried Peony 1 liang. Take 3 qian at a time, decoct in water for consumption. Xue Ji states: These are mainly substances for the Taiyin and Yangming; however, prolonged blood deficiency leads to Yang deficiency, hence insufficient blood causes numbness. It eliminates false heat and manifests various syndromes, clearly not wind. This example of uplifting Yin and Yang.

    Maimendong Yinzi: Treats a child's lips turning white, prolonged nosebleeds that do not heal.
    Schisandra 10 grains; Maimendong without hearts, Huangqi each 1 qian; Angelica root, Ginseng, Shengdi Huang each 5 fen. Decoct in water for consumption.

    Mutong San [from "Shenghui Fang"]: Treats a child's fever with no nasal discharge, dry mouth, and heart agitation, restless sleep.
    Mutong, chopped; Maimendong without hearts, roasted; Chuan Shengma each 5 fen; Zhimu, roasted bitter almonds (with skin and tips removed), lightly fried until yellow; rhinoceros horn, roasted Licorice lightly charred, each 1 fen; three Zhisou seeds. Grind these ingredients into a coarse powder. Take 1 qian per dose, using a small cup of water, decoct until reduced to 5 points, strain, and adjust dosage according to the child's size, consuming warm without time restrictions.[112p]

    　　犀角升麻散张涣方　治脑热，肺壅，鼻干病。　　犀角屑一两　川升麻　马牙硝　川黄连　朱砂研飞，各半两　牛黄　龙脑各一分，细研　　右件捣罗为细末，每服半钱，温蜜汤调下，乳后服。

    Xijiao Shengma San (Zhang Huan's Method)
    This treats heat in the brain, lung congestion, and dry nose issues.
    Ingredients:

    • 1 liang of rhino horn shavings
    • 1 liang of Sichuan Shengma
    • 1 liang of Magera Xie
    • 1 liang of Sichuan Huanglian
    • 1 liang of vermilion, finely ground, each to be used in equal halves
    • 1 fen of Niu Huang
    • 1 fen of Long Nao, finely ground

    Crush the above items into a fine powder. Each dose is half a qian, mixed with warm honey water and taken after breastfeeding.

    Mai Men Dong Wan (Complete Formula)
    This treats heat congestion in the heart and lungs of children, with a runny nose and occasional irritability.
    Ingredients:

    • 1 liang of Mai Men Dong, heart removed and roasted
    • 0.5 fen of finely ground Long Nao
    • 1 fen of roasted Gan Cao
    • 1 fen of finely ground Niu Huang
    • 1 liang of Huang Lian
    • 1 liang of Chi Fu Ling

    • 1 liang of powdered frost
    • 1 liang of vermilion
    • 1 liang of Magera Xie
    • 0.5 liang of Zi Qiao
    • 0.5 liang of raw Di Huang

    Crush these ingredients into a fine powder and mix well. Each dose is half a qian, taken with warm water.

    Long Nao San (from Sheng Hui Fang)
    This treats children's nasal issues, where they cannot smell scents or odors.
    Ingredients:

    • 0.5 qian of Long Nao, finely ground
    • 14 gourd stems
    • 30 red beans
    • 3 large stems of Huang Lian, trimmed

    Crush these ingredients into a fine powder, mixing in the Long Nao evenly. Before bed each night, blow a small amount into the nostrils with a bean, and expect a bit of clear water to emerge for effectiveness.[113p]

    　　右二味，捣末取药如豆，着绵缠，内鼻中，日二。　　又方 【《千金翼》，下同】 　治鼻中息肉，鼻中不得喘息。　　取细辛以口湿之，屈头内鼻中，傍内四畔多着，日十易之。满二十日外，以葶苈一两，松罗半两，二味捣筛，以绵薄裹如枣核大，内鼻中，日五六易之。满二十日外，以吴白矾上上者二两，瓦坯里相合，令置窑中烧之，待瓦熟取，捣筛，以面脂和，如枣核大，内鼻中，日五六易，尽更和，不得顿和，二十日外乃瘥。慎行作劳及热食、及蒜面百日。　　又　治齆鼻有息肉，不闻香臭。[114p]

    Qing Fei Gao by Zhang Huan, for treating nasal diseases.

    Half a tael of melon stem, one piece of prepared aconite (peel and navel removed), one fen each of red beans, fine cinnamon, and licorice. Grind these ingredients into a fine powder, add one qian of dragon brain, mix well, and knead with honey to form pills. Wrap them in cotton and insert them inside the nose, adjusting to the size of the nostrils.

    There are two prescriptions: the first is suitable for those with heat, while the second is for those with cold.

    Tong Xin San Qian Jin Fang, for treating children's nasal congestion causing nasal polyps.

    One tael each of Tong Cao (ventilating herb) and fine cinnamon. Grind these two ingredients into powder, form pills as big as beans, wrap in cotton, and insert into the nose twice daily.

    Another prescription (same as in "Qian Jin Yi") for treating nasal polyps that obstruct breathing: moisten fine cinnamon in the mouth, bend the head and insert it into the nose, apply generously around the inner sides, and change it ten times a day. After twenty days, use one tael of Lingzhi seeds and half a tael of pine resin, grind and sift the two ingredients, wrap in thin cotton to form pills the size of jujube seeds, and insert into the nose five to six times a day.

    After twenty days, take two taels of high-quality Wu Bai Fan (white alum), mix it with pottery clay, and burn it in a kiln until the pottery is done, then grind and sift it. Mix with face grease to make pills the size of jujube seeds and insert into the nose five to six times a day. It’s important not to blend too quickly, and treatment should continue for twenty days for recovery. Be cautious to avoid exertion and hot foods, as well as garlic, for one hundred days.

    Another remedy for nasal polyps causing loss of smell.[114p]

    Gourd Stems

    Half a liang of gourd stems and half a liang of Xixin.

    Realgar Powder (Danxi)
    Used to treat children with red noses.
    Equal parts of realgar and yellow dan. To use, mix with rootless water for application, or grind half a leaf of calamus, steam with wine into a powder, and take it as a remedy to relieve food poisoning. The rootless water refers to rainwater collected in a bowl.

    Chrysanthemum Powder (Zhang Huan’s Formula)
    Used for nasal congestion and excessive mucus.
    One liang each of sweet chrysanthemum, fengfeng (Siler), and before the plant (Hao), and one fen of licorice. Half a liang each of Xixin and cinnamon heart.
    Crush the above ingredients into a fine powder. Each dose is half a qian, mixed with a small amount of frankincense, and decocted with a broth of fine Jiangjie (Schizonepeta) to be taken after breast milk.

    Chrysanthemum Powder (Shenghui’s Formula)
    Used for children suffering from cold wind injuries, with excessive mucus in the nose and mental dullness.
    One fen each of sweet chrysanthemum, baizhu (Atractylodes), Xixin, baizhu (white Poria), roasted licorice, fengfeng, and ginseng.
    Crush these ingredients coarsely into a powder. Each dose is one qian, taken with a small cup of water, adding a little fresh ginger, and decocted until reduced to one-fifth. Strain out the residue, and depending on the child’s size and condition, adjust the temperature and amount for consumption.[115p]

    Children's Head, Face, Ear, Eye, Nose Illnesses

    Single Prescription
    To treat children's wind in the skull:
    Use ground snake skin and mix it with the marrow from the pig's cheek. Apply to the top of the head three to four times a day.

    Also: Use pig’s tooth and cheek marrow, boil and apply to the fontanelle for recovery.

    To treat children's head growth that does not fuse: thin and yellow in color, unable to walk by ages four or five:
    Use one sheng each of pinellia, fresh ginger, and xiong yao, three liang of asarum, one foot of cinnamon bark, and ten pieces of prepared aconite (chopped). Soak them in five sheng of strong bitter wine, simmer for three boils. Strain and take a piece of cotton soaked in the medicine, adjusting the temperature between warm and cool to apply on the fontanelle. Alternate cool and warm and apply as before, three to four times each morning and evening until stopping. Complete the treatment within twenty days for recovery.[116p]

    　　治小儿解颅，用生蟹足、白蔹各半两，捣末，以乳汁和敷颅上，立愈。
    　　治小儿解颅：以细辛、桂心各半两，干姜十八铢为末，以乳汁和敷颅上，干复敷之，儿面赤即愈。一方用姜汁和敷顖上。
    　　治小儿顖开不合：用防风一两，柏子仁、白芨各一两，为末，以乳和敷顖上，日一，十日知，二十日愈。
    　　小儿解颅，顖开不合鼻塞者：天南星炮去皮为末，淡酢调绯帛上贴顖门，炙手频熨之，立效。【《小儿直诀》】

    　　小儿顖门生下即肿者：黄蘗末水调贴足心。 【《普济方》】

    To treat a child's head opening, use half a catty each of live crab legs and white vine, crush them into powder, mix with milk, and apply to the head for immediate effectiveness.

    To treat a child's head opening: take half a catty each of asarum and cinnamon heart, and 18 grams of dried ginger, reduce to powder, mix with milk, and apply to the head; cover again. If the child’s face turns red, it will heal. Another method uses ginger juice for application on the fontanelle.

    To treat a child’s fontanelle that is not closing properly: use one catty of saposhnikovia, and one catty each of bunai seed and white lily root, grind into powder, mix with milk, and apply to the fontanelle. Do this daily; in ten days, you will see improvement; in twenty days, it will heal.

    For a child with a head opening and nasal congestion: grind tian nanxing (jack-in-the-pulpit) after removing the skin, mix with diluted vinegar, and apply to the fontanelle. Use a heated hand to press frequently for immediate effect.

    For a child's head opening: roast the head of a yellow dog and grind it to a powder, then mix with egg white and apply.

    To treat a child's head opening: drip blood from the comb of a rooster onto it and then dust with red peony powder; this is very effective.

    For a child's soft and swollen fontanelle: mix indigo with cold water and apply, along with taking detoxifying pills.

    If a child's fontanelle swells immediately after birth: mix coptis powder with water and apply to the soles of the feet.

    For a child's sunken fontanelle due to internal obstruction and lack of blood and qi: use one catty of black chicken bones roasted until yellow, and two catties of raw rehmannia baked into powder, taking half a qian mixed with rice drink.[117p]

    　　小儿顖陷乃冷也，水调半夏末涂足心。 【《本草纲目》】

    • When a child's fontanel sinks, it indicates coldness; apply a mixture of Banxia and water to the soles of the feet.
    • For a child's fontanel sinking: use two qian of prepared Aconite and two qian of peeled Fuzi, ground with eight fen of realgar into a powder, and mix it with crushed scallion roots to form a cake and apply to the sunk area.
    • To treat a child's fontanel sinking: roast the crown of the head until yellow, then grind it into powder and apply with raw oil.
    • For a child with a soft crown, due to wind deficiency: take a piece of stone from a snake, calcine it seven times, soak it in vinegar seven times, grind it with turmeric into powder, add a little musk, and form small pills the size of longan with white rice; take one pill with peppermint soup once a day.
    • A soft crown in a child indicates liver and kidney deficiency, with wind evil invading; use two qian each of peeled Fuzi and Tian Nanshen, grind them into powder, mix with ginger juice to form a paste, apply to the Tianzhu bone, and take Qingwan internally.

    　　治三日小儿头面疮起，身体大热：用升麻、柴胡、石膏各六铢，甘草、当归各十二铢，大黄、黄芩各十八铢，(口父)咀，以水四升煮取二升，分服，日三夜一，量儿大小用之。

    For treating a young child with sores on the head and face and a high fever lasting three days: use six qian each of Shengma (Scutellaria), Chaihu (Bupleurum), and Shigao (Gypsum); twelve qian each of Gancao (Licorice) and Danggui (Angelica); eighteen qian each of Dahuang (Rhubarb) and Huangqin (Scutellaria).     For treating sores all over the child's body and head: use Ulmus bark, dried in the sun according to how much is available, then grind it to powder and mix with vinegar to use as a poultice, applying it to the sores to draw out the insects.     For treating head sores, or yellow and rotting hot sores on the body, as well as scabies and skin erosion: use five sheng of Yimucao (Motherwort) and Tianmacao (Gastrodia), cut into pieces, boiled in one and a half dou of water, then use the resulting decoction to wash the affected areas multiple times to relieve itching.

    For children's head sores and bald patches that do not heal for years: take dust from the beams of a house, mix it with sediment from an oil jar, and use a soap pod decoction to wash and apply. Additionally, apply oil from large insects, which is also effective for white baldness.

    Furthermore, for sores that appear on the scalp with white tops: they can be treated by applying bear bile.

    For treating children's head sores: take one liang of Huafen (white powder) and two liang of Huanglian (Coptis), grind into a powder, apply to the dry scab, and it will heal; if hair regrows, apply again as before.     To treat chronic scalp sores: Apply a fine powder of huanglian (Coptis) to the affected area.

    To treat chronic scalp sores: Take ku shen (Sophora flavescens) pills after a meal. Externally, use ku shen powder mixed with oil, and recovery will occur in two months. Additionally, use red-hot charcoal to heat and wash the area with running water, then prepare pig fat by boiling cilantro seeds to remove impurities, and apply the fat to the affected area. Another method involves grinding cilantro seeds, dragon liver, dragon tail, huanglian, and white alum into a powder and mixing it with oil for application. Alternatively, applying winter horse fat oil to the affected area has been reported to be extremely effective.

    To treat soft sores on a child’s head: Slice fresh persimmons thinly, including the skin, dry them, and grind them into a fine powder. When using, first wash the area with warm water and squeeze out the pus and blood. Take a small amount of the powder, mix in one-third of a portion of talcum powder until combined, then use some thin cowhide glue to form a paste and apply it on a piece of cloth to stick onto the sore.

    Another method: Use hot and fried sesame from a pan, mash it, and apply it directly. Another method: Use a thin cake of raw oil dough, leaving a hole for the sore, and it will allow the pus to come out by the next day. This has been repeatedly verified.     　　一用乌牛胆点之。

    To treat a child's red eyes due to cold or wind, take two expelled roundworms from a child, store them in a magnetic box, seal it with paper, bury it in damp earth, and after five days, retrieve it to turn into water, which should be kept in a magnetic bottle.     For a child’s night blindness: apply blood from the top of a sparrow's head frequently.

    For a child’s night blindness: consume raw cow liver.

    Use black cow bile for application.

Serve after warming through soup, ingesting on an empty stomach. Sweet wine with a bit of warm white wine is also good. Continue until the eyes clear and the mist dissipates.[137p]

    　　小儿目睛上生白膜：以白矾一分，水四合，于热铜器中煎取半合，下白蜜调之，用绵滤过，每用芥子许点之，日三。【《卫生总微》，下同】

    　　治雀目：以黄蜡不拘多少，器内熔成汁，取下，入蛤粉相和得所，团成毯子。每用以刀子切下一二钱许，以猪肝一二两批开，掺药在内，麻缕札，水一碗铫内煮熟，乘热气熏眼，至温时并肝食之，神效，日二服。　　又：以豆豉于新瓦上炒令黄色，入雄黄半两，同研为细末。每用药一钱，豮猪肝一片批开，掺药裹合，陈米饮煮熟与食之。　　又：以石膏为细末，每用一钱，猪肝一片薄批，掺药在中，麻缕缠定，入砂瓶中煮熟，切作块子与食。此方治诸药不效者，服之如神。

    Treatment for Eye Problems:
    Use yellow wax in any amount, melt it in a container to create a juice, take it out, and mix it with clam powder to form a paste. Each time, cut off about a couple of cents worth, and mix it with a piece of pig liver weighing one or two taels, place the medicine inside, bind it with hemp thread, and cook it in a bowl of water until done. Use the steam to fumigate the eyes, and when it’s warm, consume the mixture with the liver, which is very effective. Take twice daily.

    Additionally: Fry fermented soybeans on a new tile until they turn yellow, then add half a tael of realgar and grind it into a fine powder. Each time, use one cent of this medicine, take a piece of pig liver, open it up, fill it with the medicine, and cook it with aged rice soup until done, then eat it.

    Also: Use gypsum as a fine powder. Each time, take one cent, slice a piece of pig liver thinly, put the medicine inside, bind it with hemp thread, put it in a sand jar, and cook it until done. Cut into pieces and eat. This method works like a charm for those who have tried other medications without success.

    For Children's Eye Malnutrition:
    Take equal parts of black bass fish bones and oysters, grind them into a fine powder, and form into round pills the size of soap. Use one pill at a time, and together with a piece of pig liver, add the medicine into clear rice water and cook until the liver is done to the right degree, then consume the liver along with the juice.

    For Treating Grass Seeds Stuck in the Eye:
    Use a new cloth to cover the eye and hold a larvae on the cloth to rub against it, until the seeds come out and stick to the cloth, which is very effective.[139p]

    To treat various substances that have entered the eye and do not come out: Use good ink and clear water to grind into juice, and use a copper chopstick to touch it, and it will come out immediately.

    To treat red, swollen, painful eyes: Take tender locust buds or leaves, boil them to make a decoction, let it cool, and wash the eyes with it. This is especially effective if the whites of the eyes are bloodshot and there are many tears.

    For children with nasal congestion and fever: Take one tael of fumitory and three taels of sheep marrow, simmer in a pot over low heat until it becomes a paste, strain, and apply to the back three to four times a day.

    　　　　　针灸

    　　《千金方》曰：小儿顖陷，灸脐上下各半寸，及鸠尾骨端；又足太阴各一壮。　　《医学纲目》曰：顖门不合，脐上脐下各五分二穴，灸三壮，灸疮未发先合。　　《古今医统》曰：小儿陷顖，灸水分七壮，禁针。水分在下脘下一寸，脐上一寸，穴当小肠下口，至是泌别清浊，水液入膀胱，渣滓入大肠，故曰水分。或针长强三分，灸则五壮。长强一名气之阴郄，一名撅骨。在脊骶骨端，计三分，伏地取之乃得，足少阴、少阳结会督脉，别走任脉。[142p]

    If there is nasal congestion preventing the sense of smell and continuous nasal discharge: use half a scoop of the herb spina date seed, grind it into a fine powder, and simmer it in a small cup of water until it reduces by half. Have the patient lie on their back, take a mouthful of rice to hold, and pour the medicinal liquid into the nose. After doing this twice, the sickness will be expelled by sneezing. This condition occurs in older children, but not in younger ones.

    To treat pus-filled sores in the nose: take the dirt from the ears of a black cow, clear the pus from the nose first, then apply it.

    To treat a runny nose with retained flesh, making breathing uncomfortable and affecting the sense of smell: wrap powdered alum in cotton without mixing it with grease, and place it in the nose for several days until the retained flesh is expelled with the medicine.

    Acupuncture

    The "Thousand Golden Prescriptions" states: for children with an inwardly sunken fontanel, cauterize half an inch above and below the navel, as well as the tip of the tailbone; also perform one moxibustion on each foot's Taiyin point. The "Medical Guidelines" states: if the fontanel is not closed, moxibustion should be applied to the points half an inch above and below the navel with three applications, cauterizing before sores develop. The "Ancient and Modern Medical Compendium" states: for children with a sunken fontanel, perform moxibustion on the Shuifen point seven times, and avoid acupuncture. The Shuifen point is located one inch below the xiphoid process and one inch above the navel, corresponding to the lower orifice of the small intestine. This is responsible for separating clarity from turbidity; fluids enter the bladder, waste into the large intestine, hence the term 'water division.' Alternatively, if using acupuncture, a length of three-tenths can be applied, and five moxibustions are then needed. Changqiang is also named Qizhi Yinque and Juegu, located at the tip of the sacral spine, measured at three-tenths; it must be accessed by lying prone. The points of the foot's Shaoyin and Shaoyang converge with the Governing Vessel and branch off to connect with the Conception Vessel.[142p]

    　　《原机启微》曰：治小儿雀目，夜不见物，灸手大指甲后一寸内廉，横文头白肉际，灸一壮，炷如小麦大。　　《卫生宝鉴》曰：小儿疳眼，灸合谷二穴各一壮、炷如小麦大，在手大指次指两骨间陷者中。　　《医学网目》曰：小儿乳癖目不明者，灸肩中俞二穴各一壮。在肩甲内廉去脊二寸陷中。　　《古今医统》曰：小儿三五岁，两眼每至春秋忽生白翳遮瞳子，疼痛不可忍，灸大椎上一壮。　　小儿斑疮入眼，灸大椎二穴，顶后第一椎下两傍各一寸半。　　小儿目濇怕明，状如青盲，灸中渚二穴各一壮，左手小指次指大节后陷中。　　小儿热毒风盛，眼晴疼痛，灸手中指本节头三壮，名拳尖也。[143p]

    The "Genji Qiwei" says: For treating children with squint who cannot see at night, moxibustion should be applied one inch inward from the big toe's nail at the horizontal white meat junction, using one large cone of moxa, about the size of a small wheat grain.

    The "Weisheng Baojian" says: For children with malnutrition-related eye issues, moxibustion should be applied at each of the He Gu points, using one large cone, about the size of a small wheat grain, located between the two bones at the base of the big and index fingers.

    The "Yixue Wangmu" says: For children with blurry vision due to milk nodules, moxibustion should be applied to two Zhong Yu points on the shoulder, each with one large cone, situated two inches from the spine at the inner edge of the shoulder blade.

    The "Gu Jin Yi Tong" says: For children aged three to five, if they suddenly develop a white film covering their pupils during spring and autumn, with unbearable pain, moxibustion should be applied to the Dazhui point with one large cone.

    If a child has variola affecting the eyes, moxibustion should be applied to two Dazhui points, located one and a half inches to either side beneath the first cervical vertebra.

    For children who are sensitive to light and have symptoms resembling a "blue blind," moxibustion should be applied to both Zhong Zhu points with one large cone, located in the depression at the base of the middle finger and the adjacent finger.

    For children with severe heat and wind causing eye pain, moxibustion should be applied to the head of the middle finger's first joint three times, known as the "fist tip."[143p]

    　　　　　医案

    　　万氏《幼科发挥》曰：一儿颈细，其父常问于予，可养何如？予曰：颈者头之柱也，颈细则不能任元，在父母调养之，八岁后再议。至五岁死。
    　　一儿解颅，未一岁，认字念书，父母甚爱之。予曰：此儿胎禀不足，肾虚解颅，真阳弱矣；聪慧早发，真阳泄矣。恐贻父母忧。未一岁而发搐死。
    　　一儿头缝四破，皮光而急，两眼甚小。予曰：脑者髓之海也。肾主骨，髓中有伏火，故髓热而头破，额颅大而眼楞小也。宜服地黄丸。父母不信，至十四岁而死。[144p]

    Medical Cases

    In Wan's "Elaboration on Childhood Medicine," it is stated: A child with a thin neck was often inquired about by his father regarding proper care. I replied: The neck is the pillar of the head; if it is thin, it cannot support the essence. Care should be taken by the parents, and we can discuss it again after he turns eight. Unfortunately, he died at the age of five.

    Another child had a cranial deformity and was not yet one year old. He could recognize characters and read, and his parents were very fond of him. I said: This child has insufficient prenatal endowment; the kidney is weak, and the true yang is inadequate. His intelligence developed early, leading to a leakage of true yang. I fear this will worry the parents. He passed away before reaching one year, having experienced convulsions.

    A third child had four sutures open on the head, with a smooth and tight scalp, and very small eyes. I said: The brain is the sea of marrow. The kidneys govern the bones; with hidden fire in the marrow, it becomes hot, leading to a fractured skull. A large forehead and small eyes are the result. It would be advisable to take Rehmannia Pills. However, the parents did not believe this, and the child died at the age of fourteen.[144p]

    　　一小儿头患疖甚多，寒热作痛，时季夏，乃形病俱实。先用人参败毒散加黄连、香薷一剂，其痛顿止。次用仙方活命饮，未三服，大者出脓，小者自消。后食厚味复发，用清胃散、活命饮各一服而愈。
    　　一小儿头面肿痛焮赤，属胃经热毒。先用仙方活命饮，次用清胃散而痊。后口舌生疮。别搽末药，腹痛重坠，作呕不食，手足指冷。余谓脾胃虚寒，用异功散加升麻而痊。
    　　一小儿生旬余，头患毒高寸许，有赤晕，势危急。卧镰砭出黑血，儿即安。翌日眉间有患，亦有赤晕。余意宜砭之。众议第二日砭之。果血凝不出，腹胀而殁。
    　　一小儿头面患热毒，服清胃之药，肿痛益甚。余谓毒气炽盛而瘀血不散也。用仙方活命饮二剂而愈。后因伤食，朝寒暮热，头面仍患之。服降火之剂，口舌赤肿，手足并冷。余谓胃气腹伤而虚寒也，用五味异功散而愈。[145p]

    A young child suffered from many abscesses on the head, experiencing chills and fever, with pain persisting, particularly in summer, indicating a tangible illness. Initially, a dose of Ren Shen Bai Du San was administered, along with Huang Lian and Xiang Ru, which immediately alleviated the pain. Next, Xian Fang Huo Ming Yin was given; within three doses, the larger abscess drained pus, while the smaller ones resolved on their own. However, after eating rich food, the condition reoccurred; a dose of Qing Wei San and Huo Ming Yin each cured the ailment.

    Another young child had swelling and pain on the head and face, with redness indicating heat toxin in the stomach channel. Initially, Xian Fang Huo Ming Yin was used, followed by Qing Wei San, achieving recovery. Later, sores appeared on the mouth and tongue. Additional powdered medicine was applied; the child experienced severe abdominal pain, a heavy feeling, vomiting, and coldness in the hands and feet. I suspected spleen and stomach deficiency due to cold, and treated with Yi Gong San plus Sheng Ma, resulting in recovery.

    A newborn baby developed a poisonous swelling about an inch high on the head, with a red halo, indicating a critical condition. Cupping was performed, yielding dark blood and the child stabilized. The next day, a similar issue appeared between the eyebrows, with a red halo as well. I deemed cupping appropriate; after discussion, it was cupped on the second day. However, the blood clotted and could not be drawn out, leading to abdominal swelling and death.

    Another young child experienced heat toxin on the head and face, and after taking Qing Wei medicine, the swelling and pain worsened. I concluded that the toxic qi was intense, causing stagnation of blood. Two doses of Xian Fang Huo Ming Yin led to recovery. Subsequently, due to food injury, the child experienced morning chills and evening fevers, with a recurrence of symptoms on the head and face. After administering fire-reducing medicine, the mouth and tongue became red and swollen, with coldness in the hands and feet. Liver conditions, unless caused by liver fire or blood dryness leading to wind, are typically due to deficient liver blood causing fire. In the case of an acute condition presenting with both sickness and a vigorous appearance, it is appropriate to use laxatives like Qingwan sparingly; for chronic cases with both sickness and weak appearance, Dihuang pills should be used to nourish the kidney and liver.
